The serjeant-at-arms looks you up and down with grudging approval.

'You've survived the mud, the marching, and the misery. No longer a green levyâ€”you're one of the lads now, {PLAYER_NAME}. A proper soldier.'

You have chosen your military formation. Better equipment awaits at the quartermaster's wagon.

You're summoned to the camp headquarters as evening falls.

'Word of your deeds has reached my ears, soldier. You've shown courage and cunning where others showed cowardice. From this day, you bear the rank of {RANK}.'

You've earned your place among the veterans. The quartermaster has better gear waiting for you.

Before the assembled company at the morning muster, your lord speaks:

'Step forward, soldier. You have proven yourself worthy of greater trust. I hereby recognize you as {RANK}. Your experience and judgment are now relied upon by the men around you.'

Visit the quartermaster for equipment befitting your new station.

At dusk, as the camp settles, a runner summons you to your lord's tent.

'For valor shown and battles won, I recognize your worth. You are now {RANK}â€”a veteran of the highest order. The officers look to you for guidance in the field.'

You're approaching the pinnacle of enlisted service. The officer's provisions are now available.

Around the officers' fire, with the camp spread beneath the stars, your lord addresses the gathered veterans.

'Few soldiers ever stand where you stand today. By your blood and your blade, you have earned a place among my {RANK}â€”the finest warriors under my banner.'

You have reached the pinnacle of enlisted service. At the next tier, you may be offered command of your own retinue.

Your previous equipment ({COUNT} items) has been added to your inventory.
{LORD} remembers your hesitation at the wagon line. Return in {DAYS} days, once your affairs are in order.
I hear your company takes on capable fighters. I can handle myself in a scrap - interested?
You look useful. We pay fair coin for good work, and dead men don't collect. Fall in with the lads and keep your blade sharp.
Captain, I've been riding with the company long enough. Time we settled accounts.
You've earned your share and then some. Take your coin now and walk free, or stick around another year - I'll sweeten the pot. Your call.
I'll take my cut now. It's been good riding with you.
Coin's good, company's better. I'll stick around for that bonus.
Let me think on it. I'll find you when I've decided.
Fair winds, fighter. You've done right by the company. If you ever need work again, you know where to find us.
Smart choice. The lads will be glad to have you. Your bonus is guaranteed when the year's up. Now let's find some trouble.
Captain, the year's up. What's the score?
Another year done, and you're still breathing. Take your gold and go free, or sign on for another round - same deal as before. What'll it be?
I'll take my share. Time to see what else is out there.
The road's been good to me here. I'm in for another year.
Your coin's counted and your horse is yours. Good luck out there - and if you hear of any good contracts, send word.
Good man. The company's better for having you. Same terms, same coin - let's get back to work.
I've had my rest. Ready to get back to work, captain.
Good timing. We've got work lined up and could use another blade. Fall in with the lads.
Captain, I need to break contract early. Something's come up.
Contract's done then. No hard feelings - everyone's got their reasons. Don't expect a warm welcome if you come crawling back soon, though.
Your {UNIT_NAME} has served you well these many months. What of your men? They may return to the ranks, or... if they wish to follow you into the unknown, I shall not stop them.
My men have chosen to march with me, my lord. We've bled together - that bond does not break so easily.
Let them return to the army. They signed on to serve the kingdom, not one man.
So be it. Your {COUNT} soldiers have decided to stay with you rather than re-enlist. I've had the quartermaster set aside provisions for your journey. Fare well, soldier.
Your lads have been asking around. Word is they'd rather follow you than draw army pay. Your call, fighter.
Tell them to pack their gear. We ride together.
They're good fighters. The company needs them more than I do.
Ha! Loyal to the end, that lot. Your {COUNT} have decided to stay with you instead of signing back on. Here's some grain for the road - you'll need it. Don't be a stranger.

You must reach Tier 3 before selecting professions. Continue your service to unlock specialized roles.
You handle the everyday soldier work: picket shifts, camp chores, hauling, drill, short patrols. (+4 XP for non-formation skills)
Work nearby farms/hamlets to keep rations comingâ€”barter, levy, or quietly procure supplies. (Skills: Charm, Roguery, Trade)
Man the picket posts, patrol around the entrenchments and palisade, and call the alarm early. (Skills: Scouting, Tactics)
Run dispatches between camp headquarters, outposts, and allied banners; get through checkpoints and return with written replies. (Skills: Scouting, Charm, Trade)
Cut timber and dig; drain around tents, shore up breastworks, lay corduroy over mud, and keep tools and wagons serviceable. (Skills: Engineering, Steward, Smithing)
Post billet lists, route carts around trenches, book barns/inns, and settle accounts. (Skills: Steward, Trade)
Run the aid tent by the stockade; clean and dress wounds, set bones, and keep salves stocked. (Skill: Medicine)
Work the siege park; shape beams, lash ladders and gabions, and patch engines between bombardments. (Skills: Engineering, Smithing)
Run morning drill on the parade ground; dress ranks, time volleys, rehearse signals, and sharpen maneuvers. (Skills: Leadership, Tactics)
Specialized reconnaissance and sabotage operations behind enemy lines. (Skills: Roguery, Engineering, Smithing)

Specialized military profession.
My lord, I offer you my sword and my loyalty. Will you have me in your ranks?
Hold, friend. I see you already command men of your own. A general cannot become a foot soldier while lords still march beneath his banner. Disband your army first, then we may speak of service.
I understand, my lord. I shall see to my army's affairs first.

Ah. You again. I remember you at the wagon lineâ€”had your gear ready, then walked off. Changed your mind. I don't begrudge a man his doubts, but I need soldiers who are certain. Sort out your affairs. Come back in a week, if you're serious.
As you say, my lord. I shall return when I am ready.
The canvas flaps in the breeze. Maps and tallies cover a makeshift table. Your small corner of the army's camp.

After the Battle

The battle is won. As your men regroup, you notice soldiers from other units looking your way. Your reputation precedes you, Commander.\n\nA corporal approaches. "Sir, some of the lads want to join your retinue. What should I tell them?"
"Volunteers step forward."
Fresh faces join your ranks. They look to you with respect.
"Request formal transfers from the captain."
The captain scowls but complies. More soldiers report for duty, though your lord may not appreciate the request.
"We have enough. Tell them to return to their units."
Your men appreciate that you will not over-extend. They know you value quality over numbers.
Recognition in the Ranks

Word of your recent victory has spread through the camp. Your retinue's performance in battle has not gone unnoticed.\n\n{LORD_NAME} approaches you after the evening meal. "Your men fought well, Commander. The army could use more leaders like you."
"The credit belongs to the men, my lord."
Your lord nods approvingly. The soldiers nearby exchange pleased glances - their commander remembers who does the fighting.
"I trained them well, my lord."
"Confidence is good in a commander," your lord replies. "I shall remember this."
"With more men, I could do even better, my lord."
Your lord's eyes narrow slightly, but he nods. "Very well. I shall assign a few more to your command." You may have pushed too hard.

"Need kit? Buy it here. Wagons are dry and prices rise. If you don't like it, march naked."

Stowing Your Belongings

The quartermaster's clerk stops you, ledger in hand. 'That's civilian kit. Can't march in that. Regimental rules.'
He gestures to the wagon. 'Everything goes in storage for two hundred denars plus five percent, or I liquidate it at sixty on the denar. Your choice.'
"Fair enough. I'll pay the storage fee."

You pay the fee. The clerk hands you a chalk marker with your storage number.
'Guard that number,' he says, scratching an entry in his ledger. 'Lose it, you'll regret it.'
Your things disappear into the wagon, logged and secured. You're issued military kit. When the wagon rolls away, you feel lighterâ€”like something's been decided for you.
"I don't have that kind of coin. There must be another way."

You explain your situationâ€”honest, earnest. The clerk studies you for a moment.
He sighs. 'I shouldn't... but alright.' He waves at the wagon. 'Get it stowed. No charge. But keep this between us.'
He makes a ledger entry. Your things are logged and secured. You've made an ally here.

You explain your situation, but the clerk just shakes his head.
'Heard it all before, friend. Storage fee or liquidation. Those are the rules.' His quill doesn't waver.
You pay the standard fee. Your things are logged, but the clerk won't forget you tried to dodge payment.
"Let's talk price. That fee seems steep for a simple service."

You point out comparable storage rates in nearby towns, the wagon's current capacity, the clerk's actual workload.
He narrows his eyes, then chuckles. 'You know your business. Alrightâ€”hundred denars flat, no percentage. Fair deal.'
Your things are logged at the reduced rate. Proper ledger entry, properly secured.

You cite prices and precedent, but the clerk isn't impressed.
'This isn't a market stall, friend. Two hundred plus five percent. Those are the regulations.' He taps the ledger pointedly.
You pay the standard fee. At least your things are properly logged.
"I'll handle it myself tonight."

You wait for nightfall. The camp settles. Torches flicker low.
You slip through the shadows to the wagon line. Quiet footsteps. Quick hands. Your things disappear into a crate, hidden beneath supply sacks. No fee. No questions asked.
Two hundred denars saved.

You wait for nightfall, but the wagon guards are alert tonight.
'You lost, soldier?' One steps from the shadows, hand on his cudgel. The clerk appears, summoned by the commotion.
He looks disappointed. 'Trying to dodge the fee, were you?' He makes a note in his ledger. 'Full price. Plus an extra fifty for wasting my time.'
Your things are stored, but you've made an enemy here. And your name's been marked.
"Liquidate it all. I'm traveling light."

Your things are assessed quickly. 'Sixty on the denar,' the clerk announces. It's not fair, but you're not in a position to haggle.
Coin changes hands. He scratches a line in his ledger. 'Clean break. Easier that way.' You're issued military kit and march with the column.
No baggage to worry about. No fees. No risks. Just you and what you can carry.
"I've changed my mind."

The clerk's quill stops. 'Changed your mind.' He's seen it before.
He closes the ledger. 'Your lord won't be pleased. Go on, before anyone notices.'
You gather your things. The other soldiers don't meet your eyes. The column marches on without you.

These are dark days. But I will help if I can. What do you have?
Dark omens. Bad time for commerce. But show me anyway.
Aye, I can improve that. Good gear saves lives. Bring it here.
Upgrade work for a valued customer? Absolutely. Let's discuss the price.
Aye, I can do that. Let me reckon the cost of labor and materials.
Upgrade work for you? Sure, I know some tricks. Bring me what you've got.
You seek to improve your equipment? A wise choice. Good arms serve the righteous well.
The stars say your gear needs improvement. I can help. The spirits guide my hands.
You want me to work on your gear? Fine. But it'll cost you.
Upgrades aren't cheap. But if you've got the coin, I've got the skill.
You want work done? I'll need payment in advance. That's how it's done.
Upgrades? I suppose I could help. But don't expect a discount.
You wish my services? Very well. But the work is not free.
You want my skills? The spirits demand payment. Bring coin.
Upgrade work? I can do it. Good work costs good coin, though.
Looking to upgrade? Smart thinking. Quality costs, but it's worth it.
Upgrade work. Let me check the ledger for costs and materials.
Want me to improve your gear? I can do that. For the right price.
Upgrade work? I can assist. Quality craftsmanship honors those we serve.
Upgrade work? The omens are favorable. Bring me what needs improving.

Watched Eyes
A clerk's gaze lingers a little too long. Your name is on the slate nowâ€”and the slate gets read.
Keep your nose clean.
Back away from the easy angles.
You make a point of being seen doing things right.
Smile and move on.
If they're watching, let them watch.
You carry on, but the eyes don't leave.
A hard hand stops you by the wagons. "Inspection. Now." This isn't random. Someone remembered your name.
Take the scrutiny and keep it survivable.
They find nothing worth hanging you for. This time.
Pay it off quietly.
Coin now, questions later.
The hand relaxes. The inspection ends early.
A thin man with ink-stained fingers presents a list of numbers that don't add up. "Explain this."
Cooperate and explain.
Make it boring. Make it plausible.
The questions end. The suspicion doesn't.
Confess the smallest version of it.
Offer a clean ending to a dirty thread.
You take the hit, and the ledger closesâ€”mostly.
They have the proof. The room is quiet enough to hear the quill scratch. "Sign here."
Pay the fine and accept the punishment.
Lose coin now to keep your legs.
It hurts, but it ends. For now.
Deny it.
Make them work for it.
You walk out, but you don't walk away clean.
Extra Duty
Someone hands you a task nobody volunteers for. "You'll learn punctuality the hard way."
Do the duty.
Take your lumps and move on.
You finish it. You're tired, but the mark eases.
Mouth off.
Turn a punishment into a statement.
The statement is noted. So is your name.
You stand before a small circle of authority. No shouting. Just questions.
Own it.
Straight answers, fewer surprises.
They don't forgive, but they move on.
Blame someone else.
Save yourself. Pay later.
You keep your skin. You lose some of your people.
Promotion Blocked
Word comes down: no advancement while your discipline is in question. The road forward is closedâ€”for now.
Accept it.
Keep your head down. Serve clean.
It stings, but it's clear what you must do.
Volunteer for an unpleasant duty.
Earn your way back fast.
You pay in sweat, and the pressure eases.
Discharge Hearing
You get one chance to speak before the paper is signed. The room waits.
Plead your case.
Promise clean service and mean it.
They choose punishment over discharge. You're still in it.
Defy them.
If they want your respect, they can earn it.
The decision hardens. So do the consequences.
A comrade pulls you aside. "I trust you. Don't make me regret it."
Pay trust forward.
The bond tightens.
Not today.
Trust is still thereâ€”thinner.
Someone warns you before trouble finds you. "Heads up," they whisper. "They're looking for you."
Accept the warning and listen.
Use it. Don't waste it.
You're not alone in this company.
Wave it off.
Pride over prudence.
You still have friends. You act like you don't.
The fire circle closes without you. Conversations die when you approach.
Keep your head down.
Earn your place back quietly.
You swallow your pride and keep working.
Snap back.
Make it worse, faster.
Now it's not just cold. It's hostile.
Something you need is missing. Not lostâ€”taken. The message is plain.
Eat the loss.
Pay coin to move on.
You replace what was stolen. You don't forget.
Confront them.
Make it public. Make it messy.
You get answersâ€”or you get trouble.
Something aches in a way that isn't normal. You can feel it getting worse.
Rest and recover.
Slow down before it forces you.
You breathe, you rest, and the edge fades.
Ignore it.
Push through pain.
You keep moving, but you pay for it.
A cough turns wet. A wound looks angry. This is becoming a problem.
Seek treatment.
Time, fatigue, and a little coinâ€”worth it.
Clean bandages and bitter herbs. It starts to turn.
Push on.
You can't afford to look weak.
You stay upright. Barely.
Your vision tunnels. Your legs go soft. You either stop now, or you hit the ground.
Take bed rest.
Let your body catch up.
You lose time. You keep your life.
Stumble onward.
Refuse to stop.
You don't collapseâ€”but everyone sees you close to it.

Deck Training
Veterans gather on the foredeck at dawn. The ship rolls but they keep their footing. Time to learn balance fighting.
Focus on footwork. Train hard.
The deck pitches and rolls. Your legs burn from constant adjustment. But you're learning to fight on an unstable surface.
Go through the motions. Chat with the lads.
The veterans share sea-fighting tricks between swings. You learn a few names, share a few jokes about landlubbers.
Your stomach isn't ready for that.
You grip the rail and let the wave of nausea pass.
Shipboard Sparring
Two soldiers circle each other on the rolling deck. The crowd forms a rough ring. Fighting on a ship is different.
Fight aggressively. Use the ship's motion.
The ship rolls and you ride it, driving forward when the deck tilts your way. He stumbles. You win.
Stay balanced. Learn the ship's rhythm.
You keep your knees bent, weight centered. The match ends in a draw, but you've learned to read the waves.
Wave them off.
You're not ready to fight on a moving floor.
Salt's Lesson
The old sailor - they call him Salt - has fought more sea battles than you've had hot meals. He's willing to teach, but his lessons are hard.
Ask him to teach you.
He throws you around the deck for an hour. 'Keep your weight low. The sea fights for the man who respects her.' By the end you're bruised but wiser.
Watch him spar with another.
He moves like the deck is part of him. Every roll becomes a step, every pitch a feint. Some lessons are in the seeing.
Leave him be.
He shrugs and turns away. 'Landlubber.'
Visit the Hold
The cargo hold is accessible between watches. Your personal effects are stowed below deck.
Check on your belongings.
Everything's secure and dry. The ship's crew know how to stow cargo properly. A small comfort.
No need.
It can wait until port.
Sea Tales
Old hands gathered by the mainmast, sharing tales of storms and sea battles. A few younger soldiers listen with wide eyes.
Find a spot and listen.
Tales of terrible storms, of ships that vanished, of sea monsters and ghost vessels. You learn names, faces, the weight of shared voyages.
Share a tale of your own.
You tell your piece. They listen. By the end, you're part of the crew.
Not tonight.
You pass by the mainmast without stopping.
Sea Shanties
Someone's started a shanty. The rhythm matches the work - hauling lines, scrubbing decks. The singing is rough but keeps time.
Join the shanty.
Your voice joins the chorus. 'Heave away, haul away!' For a moment, you're not soldiers on a ship - just sailors under the sky.
Not your kind of thing.
You appreciate the music from a distance.
Ship's Grog
Grog ration's been issued. Some men are trading their share, others are drinking deep. The ship's stores have rum tonight.
Have your ration.
The grog is rough but warming. You share a laugh with the crew, feel almost human again.
Trade for extra rations.
The night becomes a blur of sea songs and swaying hammocks. You'll regret this when they call for watch.
Save your ration.
You trade it for something useful. Clear heads are valuable at sea.
Below-Decks Dice
Between the cargo and the bilge, men crouch with lanterns and dice. The ship's motion makes every roll uncertain.
Try your luck.
The dice favor you. Coins pile before you as the others curse the ship's roll.
Walk away.
You resist the temptation. For now.
Hammock Rest
Your hammock sways with the ship. The rhythm is almost soothing once you get used to it.
Sleep through your off-watch.
You sleep deeply, swaying with the sea. When you wake, the world feels slightly less crushing.
Can't sleep. Too much going on.
You push through. Sleep can wait until port.
Ship Repairs
The bosun needs hands for repairs. Rope splicing, sail patching, tar and oakum. Paid work for those willing.
Put in some work.
Honest work. Your hands are rough from the rope by the end, but there's coin in your pouch and the bosun remembers who helps.
Not today.
The bosun finds another pair of hands.
Night Watch Volunteer
The lookouts are tired. Volunteers to help scan the horizon are always welcome. Sometimes you spot things worth spotting.
Take a watch.
You spot something - flotsam from a wreck. The captain has it recovered. Finders get a share.
Let them watch.
The night is cold. You stay below.
Help the Seasick
Half the soldiers are green and miserable. The ship's surgeon could use hands to help them keep water down.
Lend a hand.
Buckets and blankets. The work is grim but the men you help look at you with gratitude. You learn what settles a stomach.
Not today.
The surgeon finds another helper.

Just watch.
You stay in the crowd. Safer bet.
Challenge the winner.

Arm Wrestling
His hand slams down. The crowd erupts. You've won respect.
Just watch.
You cheer from the sidelines. Safer this way.
Enter the contest.
Two men grip mugs. Loud cheering. Someone's about to lose their supper and their wages.
Drinking Contest
The crowd roars. Your opponent slumps. You barely remember the last round.
Let others go.
You've got other things to do.
Volunteer for the party.
Hours of tramping through woods. You return tired but carrying something for the cookpots.
A small party heads out to supplement rations. Something extra for volunteers.
Foraging Party
Keep your coin.
You watch a hand or two before moving on.
Sit in for a few hands.
A modest game near the cook fires. Low stakes, good company.
Card Game
Fortune smiles. You collect a modest pot and good company.
Walk away.
You resist the temptation. For now.
Try your luck.
Behind the supply wagons, men crouch in the dust. Higher stakes than cards.
Dice Game
The dice favor you. Coins pile before you as the others curse their luck.
Too rich for my blood.
You keep your gold in your purse. Wisdom, or cowardice? Only you know.
Put real money on the table.
Real money. Real risk. The kind of game where fortunes change hands.
High Stakes Game
Fortune favors the bold! You rake in a substantial pot. The losers eye you with new respect.
Lend a hand.
Blood and bandages. Grim work but the men look at you with gratitude.
Not today.
The surgeon finds another helper.
The camp surgeon could use hands. The wounded need water and bandages changed.
Help the Wounded
Good enough for now.
Your gear will survive another day. Probably.
Spend time maintaining your equipment.
You work methodically - cleaning rust, sharpening edges, oiling leather. Your gear is ready for whatever comes.
Oil, polish, sharpen. Keep it battle-ready. A soldier's gear is his life.
Maintain Your Gear
I need a moment to think.
You lean against a post and try to gather yourself. The world steadies, slightly. The surgeon watches from his tent, waiting. He knows you'll be back. They always come back â€” willing or otherwise.

Hands catch you as you stumble through the tent flap. The surgeon's face swims into focus, grim but determined. "Hold him down." What follows is a blur of pain and desperate work. When it's over, you're wrung out, emptied, but alive. "That was close," he says, washing the blood from his hands. "Don't let it get that bad again."
Give me a moment... need to catch my breath...

You brace yourself against the rail and try to focus. The horizon tilts and spins. Sailors watch from the rigging, waiting to see if you'll fall. The surgeon's mate hovers nearby, ready to catch you. Everyone knows what happens next. Everyone but you, apparently.

They lower you through the hatch on a rope sling. The surgeon's space is cramped, the lantern swings with each wave, but his hands are steady. What follows is a blur of pain and desperate work. When it's over, you're wrung out but breathing. "Another day of that and we'd be feeding you to the fish," he says. "Rest. That's an order."

The deck pitches beneath you and your legs won't hold. Someone catches you before you hit the planking. Voices shout over the wind â€” "He's burning up!" "Get the surgeon!" "Make a hole!"
The ship's surgeon is your only hope now. And port is days away.
Urgent Care at Sea
"Lash me to the mast. I'll ride it out."

They tie you to the mainmast with spare line, the way they do with sailors who've lost their minds. The night is endless fever-dreams of drowning, of voices calling from beneath the waves. But dawn finds you still alive. The sailors cross themselves when they cut you loose. You're not sure if that's respect or fear.
Let them carry me to the surgeon.

Your condition is worsening. The world blurs at the edges. Voices sound distant, muffled. You've seen men in this state before â€” some recovered. Some didn't.
The surgeon's tent is fifty paces away. It might as well be fifty miles.
Urgent Medical Care
I've survived worse.

You drag yourself to your bedroll and collapse. The night is long, fevered, full of strange dreams. But dawn finds you still breathing. The worst has passed â€” for now. They'll write songs about you, stubborn bastard that you are.
Get to the surgeon. Now.
"I don't trust that swill."
The sailor shrugs and takes a swig himself. "Suit yourself. Offer stands." He watches you walk away with the knowing look of someone who's been at sea longer than you've been alive.
"Hand it over."

An old hand catches your arm. "You look rough, soldier. I've got something that helps." He produces a flask â€” rum mixed with lime juice, the sailor's cure-all. "Kept half the fleet alive through worse than this."
Officers don't approve. But officers aren't the ones dying of ship fever.

The grog burns going down, lime and rum and something that might be seawater. By morning you're steadier. The old sailor just nods when you thank him. "Works better than anything the surgeon's got. Don't tell him I said that."
Sailor's Remedy
"Give me something for the pain."
"Keep your witch's brew."
She doesn't seem offended. Just watches you leave with those knowing eyes. "You'll be back," she says, soft enough that you might have imagined it.

An old woman follows the camp â€” no one knows her name, but everyone knows her remedies. Willow bark tea for fever. Yarrow poultice for wounds. Strange words muttered over the cup.
Some swear by her. Others cross themselves and walk away. Her prices are low, at least.

She presses a clay cup into your hands. The tea tastes like swamp water and despair. But by morning, the fever breaks. You feel almost human again. The old woman just nods when you thank her, like she expected nothing less.
Folk Remedy
No time for that.
There's always something. Another duty, another demand. Rest is for peacetime, and you haven't seen peace in months. You push on.
Find a quiet corner and rest.

You settle against a wagon wheel and close your eyes. Hours pass. When you wake, the world feels less sharp, less hostile. The ache persists, but it's quieter now. Still there, just... waiting. Like everything else in this life.
No time. There's work to do.
Ropes need hauling, watches need keeping. The ship doesn't care if you're sick. You push on, each step an effort against both the rolling deck and your own body.
Find a spot topside and breathe deep.

You wedge yourself into a corner near the mainmast and let the wind work. Salt air, endless horizon, the ship's steady rhythm. Hours pass. When you stir, the tightness in your chest has eased. The sea heals what it can, in its own time.

Below decks the air is thick and stale, and you can feel it making you worse. But there's a spot near the bow where the sea spray comes fresh and the wind clears your head.
The sailors call it the "healing corner." Half-joke, half-truth.
Rest on Deck

Your body aches for rest. Every step is an effort, every breath a reminder of what you're carrying. Sometimes the best medicine is time.
There's a spot by the supply wagons where nobody bothers you. Quiet. Out of the way.
Rest and Recover
"Never mind. I'll manage."
You turn away. The surgeon says nothing â€” he's seen your type before. Proud fools who'd rather die than admit they need help. He'll be ready when you change your mind.
"Forget it. I'll manage."

The surgeon shrugs as you climb the ladder back to the main deck. He's seen your type before â€” soldiers who'd rather suffer than admit weakness. The sea doesn't care about pride, though. It takes whoever it wants.

The ship's surgeon works in a cramped space near the waterline, lit by a single lantern that swings with the waves. He's seen worse, he'll tell you â€” storms, scurvy, sea-battles. Your condition barely makes him blink.
His tools are sharp. His prices are fair. Out here, there's no one else.

He examines you by lantern-light, steady hands despite the ship's roll. "Bad, but not the worst I've seen." The needle bites, the rum burns going down, but when he's done, you feel better. "Stay out of the bilge. Clean air topside. You'll mend."
Ship's Surgeon
"I need your help, surgeon."

The surgeon's tent sits apart from the others, marked by the smell of herbs and the moans of the wounded. You've seen him work before â€” steady hands, no wasted motion. His fees are fair, and his patients usually walk away.
Usually.

He examines you with clinical efficiency. "Nasty, but I've seen worse." The needle bites, the poultice stings, but when he's done, you feel the weight lift. "Rest. Don't do anything stupid." Sound advice from a man who's patched up too many soldiers who didn't listen.
Seek the Surgeon
"Surgeon. I need your help."
Too busy for that.
The camp calls you back.
Find peace.
You breathe. The noise fades. For a time, there is only stillness.
A quiet spot behind the camp. The chaos fades to a distant murmur.
Quiet Reflection
Not your problem.
The recruit will figure it out himself.
Show him how it's done.
You walk him through the movements. By the end, he's not perfect, but he's better.
A young recruit struggles with basic drills. His sergeant looks frustrated.
Mentor a Recruit
Let them go.
The night is cold. You stay by the fire.
You find something - a lost coin pouch. Finders keepers.
Join them.
A few soldiers head out to check the perimeter. Not official, just men who can't sleep.
Night Patrol
Think better of it.
You step out of line. Maybe next time.
The captain receives soldiers with complaints or requests. A rare chance to be heard.
Officer's Audience
Volunteer for a task.
The captain nods approval. Volunteers are remembered. You're on his list now.
Attend the service.
You kneel with the others. The words wash over you. The war seems far away.
Keep walking.
Faith is a private thing.
The camp priest holds a small service. Soldiers kneel in quiet contemplation.
Prayer Service
No time for that.
You push on.
Close your eyes for a bit.
You drift off. When you stir, the shadows moved but you feel lighter.
An old oak provides rare shade. A few soldiers doze against its trunk.
Quick Rest
Sleep is for the garrison.
You push through. Sleep can wait.
Get proper sleep.
You sleep deeply. When you wake, the world feels slightly less crushing.
Your bedroll looks inviting. A few hours of proper rest would do you good.
Not your thing.
You appreciate the music from a distance.
Join the singing.
Your voice joins the chorus. Off-key but heartfelt. For a moment, you're not soldiers.
Someone found a lute. The singing is terrible but enthusiastic.
Campfire Songs
Not tonight.
You pass by the fire without stopping.
Find a seat and listen.
Tales of sieges and charges. You learn names, faces, the weight of shared history.
Veterans around a fire, sharing tales. Younger soldiers listen with wide eyes.
War Stories
Keep walking.
The firelight fades behind you.
Join the circle.
The tale carries you away from camp, from war, from everything but the firelight.
A circle around the fire. An older soldier tells a tale with practiced ease.
Storytelling Circle
Not tonight.
You pass by the tent. Clear heads are useful.
Have a drink or two.
The wine is sour but the company's good. You relax, share a laugh.
Cheap wine and cheaper conversation. The sutler's tent does good business tonight.
Sutler's Tent
Buy something nice.
A small luxury. Something to remind you life isn't just marching and fighting.
Keep your coin.
You admire but don't buy. Smart soldier.
A merchant caravan arrived with goods from distant lands. Soldiers are haggling.
Merchant Caravan
Leave them to it.
The bow's not calling today.
Take some shots.
Nock, draw, release. Your groupings tighten with each round.
Straw targets behind the wagons. Archers loose arrows, correcting each other's form.
Archery Range
Not today.
You slip away before the sergeant notices.
Train hard. Focus on your form.
Sweat runs down your back. Your arms ache. But your blade feels more natural now.
The sergeant calls for formation. Men line up with their weapons, ready to drill.
Weapon Drill
Let them drill without you.
You find somewhere else to be.
Join the line.
Shoulder to shoulder. Shield up, spear out. The rhythm becomes instinct.
Sergeants putting men through shield walls and maneuvers. The basics of staying alive.
Formation Practice
Fight aggressively.
You drive him back with a flurry. He yields with a grudging nod.
Wave them off.
You toss the practice sword back. Another time.
A soldier tosses you a practice sword. The crowd forms a rough circle.
Sparring Match
Leave him be.
He shrugs and turns away.
Ask him to teach you.
He doesn't pull his blows. By the end you're bruised, but you understand things you didn't before.
The grizzled veteran eyes you. He's fought more battles than you've seen winters.
Veteran's Lesson
Long hours watching nothing happen. But the sergeant remembers who showed up.
Let someone else.
You've done your share.
The sergeant looks for volunteers for an extra watch. Thankless work, but officers notice.
Extra Duty
Not today.
The quartermaster finds someone else.
The quartermaster needs hands. Wagon wheels, tent patches, harness mending. Paid work.
Repair Work
Put in some work.
Honest work. Rough hands by the end, but coin in your pouch.
The words won't come today.
You set aside the paper. Another time.
Write honestly about your experiences.
The truth flows onto the page - the fear, the boredom, the moments of strange pride. It feels good to be honest, even if the words might worry them.
Write a reassuring letter, downplaying the dangers.
You craft careful words of safety and good fortune. No need to worry those waiting for you. The courier takes your letter with the next dispatch.
Ink, paper, and memories of another life. Someone back home might appreciate hearing from you.
Write a Letter Home
You make it through another day. The condition holds steady â€” no better, no worse. Maybe you'll beat this without the surgeon after all.
"Just a bit longer. I'll manage."
The surgeon examines you with a frown. "Should have come sooner." The treatment begins â€” rest, poultices, bitter draughts. But at least you're healing now instead of worsening.
"You're right. I'll go to the surgeon."
Somehow you make it through another day. The condition holds. The sailors look at you with new respect â€” or maybe just surprise that you're still standing.
I can't afford to be laid up. We're days from port.

The sick bay is a cramped space near the waterline, lit by a single swaying lantern. The surgeon works with practiced hands despite the ship's motion. "You'll mend," he says. "But stay here. No climbing, no watches until I say."
Take me to the surgeon's berth.

The ship pitches and rolls, and every lurch sends pain through you. Whatever ails you is getting worse â€” the cramped quarters, the stale air belowdecks, the salt in everything. No place for a sick man.
The bosun's mate finds you propped against a bulkhead, looking grey. "You need the surgeon, soldier. There's nowhere to run on a ship when sickness spreads."
Worsening at Sea

The pain is getting worse. What started as manageable is now a constant companion, stealing sleep and strength alike.
{SERGEANT_NAME} pulls you aside. "You need to see the surgeon, {PLAYER_NAME}. This isn't something you can walk off."
You know they're right. But treatment means time away from duty. And time away from duty means questions.
Condition Worsening
Turn to banditry

Why work for coin when you can take it?
The roads are full of merchants. You know how to fight. The math is simple.
Your first robbery goes smoothly. The second, too. You're becoming someone new.
Someone dangerous.
Travel to a different kingdom

A new kingdom means a clean slate. No one knows your face. No one knows your past.
The journey is long, but when you arrive, you're just another wanderer looking for work.
Perfect.
Head to the nearest town

Towns mean work. Work means money. Money means survival.
You set off toward the nearest settlement. Time to start over.

The army is gone. The war is behind you.
You stand at a crossroads â€” literally. One path leads to the nearest town. Another to the wilderness. A third toward a different kingdom entirely.
For the first time in months, no one is giving you orders. No one is watching. No one cares where you go.
You're free.
What now?
Free at Last
After the next battle.

"After the fight," you say. "Everyone's tired, distracted. Perfect cover."
The battle comes. When it's over, in the chaos of the aftermath, you simply walk away.
No one notices one more body missing from the count.
Actually... I've changed my mind.

{SOLDIER_NAME}'s face hardens. "Cold feet? Fine. But you didn't hear any of this. Understand?"
You nod. They slip away into the darkness without you.
You're still here. For better or worse.
Tonight. Before they notice.

"Tonight," you agree. "Pack light. Move fast."
You slip away in the darkness. The camp shrinks behind you. By dawn, you're miles away.
Free.
Wait for the next town.

"Town," you say. "We wait, blend in, disappear."
Three days later, the army enters {SETTLEMENT_NAME}. You simply... don't leave with them.
By the time anyone notices, you're long gone.

Night. A quiet corner of camp. {SOLDIER_NAME} and two others huddle close.
"So you're with us," they whisper. "Good. Now we need to plan."
They look at the distant campfires. "When do we go? Tonight? Wait for the next town? After the next battle when everyone's distracted?"
Every option has risks.
When Do We Leave?
{SERGEANT_NAME} nods. "That's the spirit. Keep your head down, do good work. They'll notice." A setback, not a defeat. The path forward is clear, if harder.
"I understand. I'll earn it properly."
The captain hears you out. "Convince me you've changed." You do. Or try to. "Probationary advancement. One incident, and you're back where you started." A chance.
"The decision stands. Prove yourself through action, not words." Appeal denied. You've wasted political capital.
"I want to speak to the captain. Make my case directly."
"Maybe." {SERGEANT_NAME} doesn't argue. "But politics or not, you gave them ammunition. Stop doing that." Cold comfort. True, though.
"Politics. It's always politics."
{SERGEANT_NAME} grabs your shoulder. "None of that. You're a soldier, act like one." Harsh. But sometimes harsh is what you need.
"What's the point? They'll never promote someone like me."

The promotion list goes up. Your name should be on it â€” the experience, the time served, the battles. But it's not there.
{SERGEANT_NAME} finds you staring at the roster.
"Your record, {PLAYER_NAME}. Too many marks. The captain won't sign off on promoting someone with your... history." They actually look sympathetic. "Clean it up. Prove them wrong. Maybe next time."
Next time. If there is one.
Promotion Blocked
The captain nods. "Then it's done. Turn in your equipment. You're no longer part of this army." It's over. Not with a bang, but with paperwork.
"I have nothing to say. I accept the judgment."
A long silence. "Against my better judgment... penal detail. Six months. Any incident and this offer disappears." A thread of hope. Thin as spider silk.
"We've given you chances. Too many." The captain shakes their head. "Sentence stands."
"Please â€” one more chance. I'll be different. I swear it."
"Noted." The captain's voice is ice. "Your attitude explains much." The discharge proceeds. No pension. No reference. Nothing.
"Discharge me then. This army never valued me anyway."
The captain reviews documents. Consults with officers. "Your combat record... is not nothing. Reduction in rank. Final warning. Don't make us regret this."
"Service doesn't excuse conduct. Many have served without becoming a disciplinary nightmare." No mercy.
"My service record â€” the battles, the duties, the blood I've shed for {LORD_NAME}â€”"

"Dishonorable discharge."
The words hang in the air. The captain doesn't look pleased to say them â€” or maybe they do. Hard to tell.
"Your record speaks for itself. Consistent failure to meet standards. Repeated infractions despite correction. You've left us no choice."
the company watches from the edge of the assembly. {SERGEANT_NAME}'s face is stone.
"You have one opportunity to speak before the sentence is carried out. Make it count."
Facing Discharge
It's brutal. Every muscle aches. But you don't complain, don't slack. By week's end, the sergeant gives you a curt nod. "Maybe you're learning after all."
Accept the punishment. Do the work.
"Unfair?" The sergeant's voice carries across the camp. "You want to talk about UNFAIR?" The lecture that follows is worse than the extra duty. And you've still got to do the duty.
Protest the unfairness of the punishment.
You throw yourself into every task. Best-dug latrines in the camp. Not a drop of water spilled. The sergeant notices. Grudging respect, maybe. At least you're not a whiner.
Not just do it â€” do it better than anyone. Make a point.
Turns out, yes. They can. Extended duty. Double shifts. Someone's always watching now. You've made this worse.
Do the minimum. What are they going to do, punish you more?

The duty roster goes up. Your name's on it. Again. And again. And twice more after that.
Extra duty â€” the army's favorite corrective measure. Latrine digging, night watch, hauling water, whatever's worst. Your infractions have been noticed, and this is the price.
{SERGEANT_NAME} shrugs when you look at them. "Out of my hands. Sergeant's orders."
A week of this, minimum.
Extra Duty
The captain studies you. "Accountability. That's something, at least." The punishment is firm but fair. You've shown character, if not competence.
"No excuses, sir. I failed to meet standards. I accept whatever punishment you decide."
"Interesting." The captain makes notes. "We'll be speaking to these individuals." You've deflected scrutiny. But someone's going to know you named names.
Point fingers. Others share responsibility â€” maybe more than you.
The captain raises an eyebrow. "Bold. Very well." The confrontation that follows is ugly, but you poke holes in the case. Charges reduced.
"You're in no position to demand anything." The captain's patience is gone. "Charges stand. Punishment enhanced for attitude."
"Some of these charges are exaggerated. I demand to face my accusers."
The captain listens. Nods, occasionally. "Context noted. Punishment will reflect... mitigating factors." You've bought some leniency.
"Excuses. I hear excuses." The captain's voice is cold. "Next."
Lay out the context. The pressures, the circumstances, the reasons behind each incident.

A formal hearing. The captain presides, {LORD_NAME}'s banner hanging behind them. You stand before a table of officers.
"Soldier {PLAYER_NAME}. The charges: repeated failure to maintain discipline standards, disregard for orders, and conduct prejudicial to good order."
They read from a list. Every infraction, every slip-up, documented and damning.
"What do you have to say for yourself?"
The Hearing
{SERGEANT_NAME} nods slowly. "See that it doesn't." The warning's been delivered. Ball's in your court now.
"You're right. I've been slipping. It won't happen again."
{SERGEANT_NAME}'s expression hardens. "There are always circumstances. The question is whether you rise above them." They walk away. Not convinced.
"It's not my fault â€” there were circumstancesâ€”"
A slight softening. "Just... be better. That's all I'm asking." They've stuck their neck out for you. Don't make them regret it.
"Thanks for the heads up. I mean it."
"I don't want to hear it." {SERGEANT_NAME} cuts you off. "Everyone's got complaints. Not everyone makes them the camp's problem." The message is clear: shut up and soldier.
"Maybe if the duties weren't soâ€”"

{SERGEANT_NAME} doesn't look happy.
"You're on notice, {PLAYER_NAME}. The sergeant's been keeping track â€” late to muster, sloppy kit, that business with theâ€”" they wave a hand. "Doesn't matter. Point is, you're building a reputation, and not the good kind."
They lower their voice.
"I can only cover for you so many times. Get it together."
On Notice
The surgeon gives you a bitter draught and tells you to drink water. "Not the wine. Water." Simple advice, but effective. Whatever was building passes before it takes hold.
"I should see the surgeon."
You shake it off. The soldiers around you respect the grit â€” nobody wants to serve alongside someone who collapses at the first chill.
"I'm fine. It's nothing."
You find a quiet corner and rest for a few hours. The heaviness lifts somewhat. Still not right, but better than pushing through until you collapse.
"I should take it easy today."
The ship's surgeon, a weathered man with salt-stained hands, looks you over. "Lime juice and grog," he prescribes. "And stay topside when you can. Stale air belowdecks breeds sickness." Sound advice.
Find the ship's surgeon.
You shake it off. The sailors around you nod approvingly â€” they've seen too many soldiers mewling in their hammocks. You're not one of those.
I've sailed before. It'll pass.
You find a spot near the bow where the salt wind blows fresh. Hours watching the horizon, breathing deep. The queasy feeling fades. Whatever was building seems to pass.
Find a quiet spot on deck for fresh air.

The ship rolls beneath your hammock as you wake, but something else is wrong. A deep weariness, a queasy feeling that goes beyond the usual sea-sickness. You've seen this before â€” ship fever spreads fast in close quarters.
The bosun's mate notices you looking green. "You steady? Surgeon's belowdecks if you need him. No shame in it â€” half the fresh hands catch something their first passage."
Something Not Right

You wake feeling wrong. Head thick, limbs heavy. Could be the food. Could be the cold nights. Could be the camp fever that's been going around.
{SERGEANT_NAME} notices you looking pale at morning muster. "You feeling alright, {PLAYER_NAME}? You look like you've seen better days."
It's probably nothing. But nothing has a way of becoming something out here.
Feeling Unwell

The surgeon's remedies are foul but effective. "Caught it early," she says approvingly. "Another day and you'd be in a cot for a week." Your tent-mates look relieved. Soldiers don't like watching each other waste away.
Go to the surgeon immediately.
An old veteran shows you how to brew the bark. Bitter as sin, but effective. The fever fades by morning and you avoid the surgeon's tent entirely.
Try a soldier's remedy â€” willow bark and rest.
The fever breaks by morning. You're wrung out but standing. "Hard as iron, that one," someone mutters. You'll take the compliment.
"I've had worse. I'll be fine."

They rig a canvas shelter near the mainmast where the air is clean. The surgeon's remedies are vile â€” vinegar and who knows what else â€” but the fever breaks by morning. The sea wind carries away what lingers.
Let them take me to the surgeon.
An old hand produces a flask. "Half rum, half lime juice, splash of seawater." Tastes like death, works like a charm. By morning you're shaky but standing.
Is there grog? The old sailors swear by it.
You sweat through the night in your hammock, but by dawn the worst has passed. The sailors respect it â€” no one wants to share a ship with weaklings who can't handle a rough passage.
I'll ride it out. Get me back to my hammock.

The night watch finds you collapsed on the orlop deck, burning with fever. The ship's hold reeks of tar and bilge, but your body has given out before you could reach your hammock.
Sailors haul you up, muttering about "the fever that spreads." In close quarters, sickness moves fast. The surgeon's mate appears with a lantern.
"We need to move you topside. Fresh air or this gets worse."
Ship Fever

You wake in the night drenched in sweat, then shivering, then sweating again. Your tent-mates are giving you worried looks.
"You need the surgeon," one says. "Before it gets worse."
They're right. The question is whether you can afford to be seen as weak, and whether you can afford not to be.
Fever Sets In
The surgeon's tent is dim and smells of herbs. "You're lucky," she says, mixing something. "I've seen men ignore the signs until it killed them." You'll be here a while. But you'll recover.
Submit to the surgeon's care.
You push yourself up, wave off helping hands. "I'm fine." You're not fine. Everyone knows it. But you stagger back to your tent and collapse there instead. The fever dreams begin that night.
"I just need... to rest. I'll be fine."

The sick bay is cramped and smells of vinegar, but it's better than the alternative. The surgeon works by lantern light, mixing remedies. "Lucky they caught you at the rail," he mutters. You'll recover. Eventually.
Let them take me belowdecks.

They lash you to the mainmast with spare line, as requested. The night is endless fever-dreams of drowning. Somehow you're still alive at dawn. The sailors cross themselves when they see you. Not sure if that's good or bad.
Just... tie me to the mast. I'll ride it out.

You wake to shouting. Someone is hauling you back from the rail, where you'd apparently been trying to climb in the grip of fever-dreams.
"He's burning up!" a voice calls. "Get the surgeon!"
The deck tilts and spins. Stars wheel overhead. Somewhere below, voices argue about whether you'll make it to port.
Man Overboard â€” Almost

You don't remember falling. One moment you were standing at muster, the next you're on the ground, faces swimming above you.
"Get the surgeon!" someone shouts. "Now!"
The world tilts and blurs. Your body has made the decision for you.
"Good." {SERGEANT_NAME} looks relieved. "Keep it that way." They didn't have to warn you. They did anyway. That means something.
"I'm clean. But thanks for the warning."
{SERGEANT_NAME} nods. "Just don't make me regret it." You won't. This is what a squad is supposed to be â€” watching each other's backs. Even when the enemy wears the same uniform.
"I appreciate this. More than you know."
{SERGEANT_NAME} considers. "I'll handle it. Quietly." They move off to warn the others. You're not the only one they're protecting. But you were first. That means something too.
"Anyone else in the squad need to know?"
"You sure?" You nod. Over the next hour, quiet words are exchanged. By morning, the squad is clean. The inspection finds nothing. {SERGEANT_NAME} never gets connected to the warning.
"Let me tell the others. Less risk for you."

{SERGEANT_NAME} pulls you aside after weapons inspection. Their voice is barely above a whisper.
"The sergeant's planning a kit inspection tomorrow. The captain's hound â€” looking for extra rations, misplaced gear, anything they can nail someone for."
They meet your eyes.
"Thought you should know. In case you've got anything that needs... tidying up."
This is a warning. The kind you don't give to just anyone. The kind that could get {SERGEANT_NAME} in serious trouble if anyone found out.
You're family now. the company protects its own.
The darkness beyond the firelight is cold. But at least it's honest. You know where you stand now. Sometimes that's worth more than false warmth.
Take your food and eat alone. They've made their choice.
{SOLDIER_NAME} doesn't welcome you. But they don't reject you either. A few words. A shared complaint about the food. It's not much. It's something.
Silence. They wait for you to leave. When you do, the talking resumes. You weren't part of it. You aren't now.
Try to join a conversation. Break through the ice.
{VETERAN_1_NAME} speaks up. "You know what you did." An argument follows. Ugly. But at least it's honest. Grievances aired. Not forgiven, but acknowledged.
"Nothing's going on." Flat. Final. They're not even willing to fight with you. That's worse.
"Someone want to tell me what's going on?"

They don't sugarcoat it. "You've lost their trust. The way you handledâ€”" they list examples. Each one a small betrayal you barely remember. "You want back in? Start making different choices." A path forward. Hard, but real.
Find {SERGEANT_NAME}. Ask what happened.

The fire circle again. But tonight, the gaps around you are wider. Conversations die when you approach. Laughter stops.
{SOLDIER_NAME} doesn't even look up when you sit down. {VETERAN_1_NAME} finds somewhere else to be. {RECRUIT_NAME} follows them.
{SERGEANT_NAME} watches from across the fire. Measuring. Not intervening.
You're still part of the company. Technically. But the warmth is gone. You're a stranger wearing a familiar uniform.
This is what isolation feels like.
You catch {SOLDIER_NAME} smirking. You get in their face. Words are exchanged. Maybe fists. But the message is clear: you're not a victim.
No one admits anything. No one saw anything. You're shouting at walls. You look paranoid. Dangerous. They wanted that.
Find out who did it. Make them answer.

Hours of work restoring your kit. They wanted you angry. They wanted a confrontation they could win. You deny them both. Cold. Professional. They'll get bored eventually. Or they won't. Either way, you're still standing.
Fix it silently. Don't give them the satisfaction of reacting.
The sergeant listens. Investigates, maybe. "I'll handle it." They probably won't. But it's on record now. If something happens to you, there's a trail.
Take it to the sergeant. This is beyond squad politics.
{SERGEANT_NAME} doesn't argue. The paperwork goes through. New squad, new people, fresh start. You're leaving enemies behind. Whether you're also leaving the problem behind... time will tell.
Request reassignment. This squad is done with you.

Your kit is wrong.
Nothing obvious â€” nothing that would fail inspection. But your straps are loosened. Your blade is dull. Your waterskin has a slow leak you didn't notice until half your water was gone.
Someone did this. Someone in the company.
{SERGEANT_NAME} isn't going to help. They're part of this, or they're looking the other way. Same result.
You're on your own. In a unit that wants you gone â€” or worse.
{VETERAN_1_NAME}'s face falls, then hardens. "Right. Forget I asked." They walk away. You had reasons. Good ones, probably. But something's broken now.
"Sorry, can't get involved. Too risky."

Relief floods {VETERAN_1_NAME}'s face. "Tomorrow, by the supply wagons. Just... be there." You show up. The collector sees they're not alone. The conversation stays civil. A debt renegotiated, not collected by force.
"I've got your back. When and where?"

A long pause. "What kind of favor?" You don't specify. They agree anyway. Desperate people do desperate things. You've got leverage now. Whether that's worth more than simple friendship... time will tell.
"I'll help. But you'll owe me a favor. A real one."
{VETERAN_1_NAME} hesitates. "Twenty denars. I know it's a lotâ€”" You hand it over. They stare at the coins like they're made of gold. "I'll pay you back. Every copper, I swear."
"How much do you owe? Maybe I can help directly."

{VETERAN_1_NAME} corners you after the evening meal. They look around, making sure no one's listening.
"Got a problem, {PLAYER_NAME}. Need help from someone I can trust." They pause. "That's you."
They explain: a debt from before the army. Collector's coming. If {VETERAN_1_NAME} doesn't have the coin, things get ugly â€” for them, maybe for their family back home.
"I'm not asking for money. Just... watch my back when the collector shows. Make sure things stay... civil."
{COMRADE_NAME} half-carries you across camp. The surgeon takes one look and starts working. Treatment is aggressive â€” and necessary. You're going to be out for a while. But you're going to live.
"Get me to the surgeon."

{SERGEANT_NAME} arrives, assesses, takes charge. "Surgeon. Now. No arguments." They organize a carry. The surgeon isn't gentle, but they're effective. {SERGEANT_NAME} checks on you twice. That means something.
"Get {SERGEANT_NAME}. They'll know what to do."
Whatever you had stashed works. The fever eases. Not cured, but stable. {COMRADE_NAME} watches through the night. By dawn, you're coherent again.
Wrong medicine. Or not enough. The fever climbs. You don't remember {COMRADE_NAME} carrying you to the surgeon. You're told about it later.
"There's medicine in my kit. Help me take it."
Somehow, impossibly, you ride it out. The fever breaks by morning. You're weak as a kitten, but alive. The surgeon will call it a miracle.
You're not fine. The fever spikes. You lose consciousness. When you wake, you're in the surgeon's tent anyway â€” in worse shape than before.
"I'm fine. Just need water."

Fever hits in the night.
The {CONDITION_TYPE} has become something else â€” something worse. {COMPLICATION_NAME}, the surgeon would probably call it. Infection, inflammation, your body turning against itself.
You wake drenched in sweat, shaking. {COMRADE_NAME} is there, looking worried.
"You're burning up. Can you walk?"
Walking sounds impossible. The surgeon's tent sounds very far away.
Sheer will keeps you present. You hear the surgeon's instructions. Feel them working. Pain means alive. You cling to the pain.
Darkness takes you anyway. When you wake, it's over. You don't know how long you were out.
Fight to stay conscious. You need to... something.
Words come out. Maybe coherent. {SERGEANT_NAME} nods. "We know. Rest now." You said what needed saying.
Just sounds. No words. Then nothing.
Try to tell them something. Important.
You stop fighting. The darkness is almost peaceful. When you wake, it's to the surgeon's tent, the smell of herbs, and {COMRADE_NAME} dozing in a chair beside you. Still here.
Let go. Trust them to fix this.

You collapse.
One moment you're standing, the next you're on the ground. Voices around you, distant and echoey. Someone's shouting for the surgeon. Someone else is pressing something against the {CONDITION_LOCATION}.
The sky is very bright. Or very dark. Hard to tell.
{SERGEANT_NAME}'s face swims into view. Their mouth moves. The words don't reach you.
Everything goes sideways.
Tastes terrible. Works anyway. Functional by morning.
Herbs don't help. Still aching. Needed a professional.
"Got herbs in my kit."
You push through. It fades. Body knows what it's doing.
Doesn't fade. Worse by evening. Should've listened.
"I'm fine. Back to it."
You sleep hard that night. By morning, it's fading. Maybe nothing after all.
"Just tired. Need sleep."
The surgeon looks you over. "Caught it early. Smart." Day's treatment. Back to normal.
"Should see the surgeon."

Something's wrong.
Starts small. Fatigue that won't lift. An ache that wasn't there yesterday. You tell yourself it's nothing. The march. Bad sleep. The usual.
But it's not lifting.
{COMRADE_NAME} catches you wincing. "You alright?"
Feeling Unwell
{REMEDY_NAME} does the trick. The symptoms ease. Not cured, but manageable. And you didn't have to explain anything to the surgeon.
The remedy does nothing. Or makes it worse. You've wasted time you didn't have.
Find some herbs, treat yourself.
You power through. The symptoms peak, then start to fade. Natural recovery, or maybe just stubbornness. Either way, you're still standing.
Your body disagrees. The {SYMPTOM_1} spikes. You stagger. {COMRADE_NAME} catches you. "Get the surgeon. Now."
Keep pushing. It's not that bad.
You scale back. Light duties only. Sleep when you can. It's not the surgeon's tent, but it's not reckless either. Slow recovery begins.
Take it easy. Rest without formal treatment.

The surgeon takes one look and scowls. "Why didn't you come sooner?" Treatment begins. It's not pleasant, but it's working. A few days rest and you'll be functional again. Should've done this earlier.
Finally give in. See the surgeon.

It's worse today.
What started as a manageable {CONDITION_TYPE} has become something harder to ignore. The {SYMPTOM_1} is constant now. {SYMPTOM_2} makes sleep difficult.
You've been pushing through. The army doesn't stop for one soldier's discomfort. But your body is sending messages you can't keep ignoring.
{COMRADE_NAME} notices you wincing. "You should see the surgeon."
Maybe they're right.
Collect aggressively
You don't ask twice. A firm grip, a hard stare, a mention of consequences. They pay. Quickly.
You shake your head. Someone else will do it.
Collect politely
You knock on doors. Remind them of obligations. Most pay â€” eventually. The lord gets their coin, and you get noticed.
Skim some for yourself
You collect the debts. Most of it goes to the lord. A portion finds its way into your pocket. No one's counting that closely.

The lord is owed money. Merchants, minor nobles, old debts gathering dust. Someone needs to collect.
{SERGEANT} mentions they're looking for volunteers. "Delicate work. Requires... persuasion."
Do this right, and the lord remembers. Maybe pay comes faster.
Collect Debts
You have other duties. Someone else takes the job.
Volunteer for the escort

The merchant arrives safely. Goods delivered. The lord nods when they hear your name.
"Good work. I won't forget."

A merchant owes the lord goods, not gold. Cloth, iron, supplies. They're willing to deliver â€” but the roads are dangerous.
"Need an escort," {SERGEANT} says. "Three days, maybe five. Volunteer, and the lord owes you a favor."
Escort Merchant
Use charm and persuasion

Words flow. You paint pictures of future profits, of stability, of opportunity. The moneylender hesitates... then nods.
"Very well. Tell your lord they have their loan."
The lord's finances aren't your problem. You walk away.
Use intimidation

You lean close. Mention certain... consequences. The moneylender's face goes pale.
"Fine. Fine! Take the money. Just... leave."
Offer your own savings

You hand over your coin. Every denar you've saved. The lord stares.

Beg for mercy

Midnight Opportunity
"Ten lashes. Then back to duty. This never happened."
The lashes are administered. The man takes his punishment without a word. He returns to his tent, bloodied but still one of yours. Some think you were merciful. Others think you were cruel.

The man's eyes widen. He nods, returns to his tent. Your officers disapprove, but your soldiers see a commander with a heart. Whether that's wisdom or weakness remains to be seen.
"Desertion is punishable by death. Report to the provost."
The man is dragged away. In the morning, the army's justice is carried out. Your men stand silently. No one else will try to run. But they won't forget what you did.
Night watch caught a soldier trying to desert. He stands before you, trembling. "Commander... my nerve broke. I just wanted to go home."
The Runner
"Both of you. Extra watch duty. Tonight. Now get out of my sight."
Neither man is happy, but they separate. Order is maintained. Your officers approve of the swift discipline.

Fists fly. It's over quickly. Both men shake hands afterward, the matter settled the old way.

Trouble in the Ranks

You set up a sick tent and assign the surgeon to watch them. The army marches ahead. In a week, your men recover. They remember you didn't leave them to die.
Three soldiers are down with fever. The camp surgeon warns it could spread if not isolated.
"Pay for a proper healer. Spare no expense."
You pay for proper medicine and skilled care. Within days, your soldiers recover fully. Word spreads - your commander pays for healing. That means something to men who face death.
Fever in Camp
"I am sorry. We may see battle any day. I cannot spare you."
His face falls. He nods slowly, knowing your words are true but hating you for them. The men mutter among themselves. Some things matter more than war.
"Go. Family comes first. Be back in seven days."
The man's face lights up. He grabs your hand, thanking you over and over. The other soldiers see this. They know you are not heartless.
"You cannot go. But take this gold and send a fast rider with gifts for your wife."
He hesitates, then accepts the coin. It's not what he wanted, but it's something. The men see you tried to help. That counts for something.

A Soldier's Plea
"I will remind them why they follow me."
You try to rally your men, but your words ring hollow. You lack the presence to truly inspire them. Still, some appreciate the effort.
You address your men with passion and conviction. Your words stir their hearts. They remember why they chose to follow you into battle.

Three of your soldiers desert in the night. The remaining men are shaken but realize you will not beg them to stay.

You buy a round for your soldiers. Laughter and song fill the camp. Your men are grateful to serve under a commander who values them.

Your soldiers nod in respect. The bond between you and your men grows stronger. They would die for you without hesitation.
Devoted Soldiers
"Good. Then you are ready for harder training."
Your soldiers grin at the challenge. They trust you to make them better warriors. Training begins at dawn.

You gather your men and hear their grievances. With a few small gestures and promises, spirits lift. Your soldiers know you care about their wellbeing.
"They will settle down on their own."
You do nothing. The discontent festers. Your soldiers notice your indifference, and morale sinks further.
Your men have grown restless. You hear grumbling during the evening meal, and discipline is slipping. Something needs to be done before morale deteriorates further.

Discontent in the Ranks

You dismiss the ringleaders without mercy. Five men are sent away. The remaining soldiers see you will tolerate no insubordination.

You empty your purse. Your soldiers are stunned by the gesture. The crisis passes. They will follow you again, though trust must still be rebuilt.

Your lord hesitates, then agrees. You get a handful of archers for cover. Your men see you negotiated for their lives. They appreciate the effort.

Your lord nods approvingly. Your men hold the line. Some fall, but the army escapes. Your lord remembers your sacrifice. Your soldiers remember being sacrificed.

{VETERAN_1_NAME} sees you. Their eyes meet yours. They don't say anything. But they saw.

{SERGEANT_NAME} pulls you aside after evening meal. Their voice is low, eyes checking that no one's close enough to hear.

They lean closer.

The Warning
Hold position and fight
You plant your feet and fight whoever comes at you. The ambushers break when they realize you're not running. Your blade is slick with blood, but you're still standing.
Rally the men
'Form up! Shields together!' Your voice cuts through the chaos. Men respond, forming a defensive line. The ambush falters against organized resistance.

Give it to a comrade who fought harder

Leave it with the dead
You leave the item where it lies. The dead deserve their dignity, and you don't need trinkets to remember this day.
A fallen enemy carried a fine blade, an ornate helmet, or a banner worth keeping. You could take it as a trophyâ€”a memento of what you survived today.
Take the trophy
You claim the item and attach it to your gear. Other soldiers nod with approvalâ€”a warrior's right to spoils.
Battle Trophy
Keep it hidden
You slip the item into your pack, covering it with a torn cloak. Your heart pounds, but no one saw. You hope.
Hide it and sell it in town later
You know a merchant who won't ask questions. You tuck the item away, planning your next visit to town. This could be profitable.

While sifting through the aftermath, you notice something valuable half-buried in the mudâ€”a well-crafted weapon, a noble's signet ring, or a pouch of foreign coin. It's worth more than a soldier's pay for a month.

Turn it in to the quartermaster
