You dig alongside the others in silence. The work is hard, but it feels right. These men deserve better than a shallow pit.
Move on, there's work to do
You turn away. Death is part of this life. Sentiment won't bring them back, and the living need attention too.
Pay your respects quietly
You stand at a distance, watching the detail work. You say nothing, but someone notices you there. It's enough.
Someone you knew is dead. Not well, perhapsâ€”a face from the campfire, a voice from the marchâ€”but dead all the same. Burial detail is forming. They could use another pair of hands.
Fallen Comrade
Keep quiet about it
You pocket the papers without a word. This information could be worth something to the right buyer. Or it could get you killed.
Read them first, then report
You scan the documents quicklyâ€”troop movements, supply routes, a name that might matter. Knowledge is power. You bring them to the captain, keeping what you learned to yourself.
Report the find immediately
You gather the papers and bring them to the captain. His eyes widen as he reads. 'Good work, soldier. The lord will hear about this.'

A dead officer lies in a ditch, his satchel spilled open. Papers flutter in the windâ€”maps, orders, possibly valuable intelligence. You could take them to your lord, or you could see what they say first.
Enemy Documents
Find the other soldiers
An older soldier sees the look on your face and nods. 'First one's the hardest,' he says quietly. 'Gets easier. Shouldn't, but it does.' You don't feel better, but you feel less alone.
Let it sink in

You find a quiet spot and sit for a long moment, staring at nothing. Something has changed in you. The trembling stops. When you stand, you're differentâ€”harder, maybe, but steadier. This is what you came here to become.
Push it down, move on
You shake your head and force your legs to carry you forward. There's no time for this. Not here, not now. You bury it deep, with all the other things you don't think about. It works. For now.
You stare at your hands, still trembling. The blood isn't yours. You remember the momentâ€”the shock on his face, the way he fell. If this was your first, it's hitting you now.
The First Kill
Linger for a proper goodbye
You break from the column for a moment. Words are exchanged, perhaps a touch. The sergeant shouts your name, and duty reclaims you.
A quick wave and keep moving
You raise a hand, hold their gaze for a moment, and then turn back to the road. It's enough. It has to be.
Someone you met during your stay doesn't want you to go. They stand at the edge of town, watching the column form. A wave, a lingering lookâ€”this is the life of a soldier.
Leave without looking back
You keep your eyes on the road ahead. Attachments are a liability. The march continues, and the town disappears behind you.
The Farewell
Grit your teeth and march
You force yourself forward, step by agonizing step. The day is miserable, but you don't fall behind. The sergeant notices your suffering but says nothing.
Find a remedy from the surgeon
The surgeon gives you a bitter tonic and a knowing look. 'This will help,' he says, 'but next time, drink less.' The relief is immediate.
Ask for a delay to recover
The sergeant is not amused. 'March now or face discipline,' he growls. You join the column, shame burning worse than the headache.
The company is preparing to march. Your head pounds like a war drum, and every ray of sunlight feels like a blade. You drank too much last night, and now you're paying for it.
Morning After
Trust to luck and save your coin

You wave the merchant off. The road will reveal its secrets soon enough. As the column marches, you notice the merchant approaching an officer instead. Someone else will get credit for that intelligence. Your coin stays in your purse, but so does your opportunity.
Pay for the information
You hand over coin, and the merchant talks. His information proves accurateâ€”the patrol avoids an ambush, and the company saves time. Money well spent.
Scout the road yourself
You ride ahead of the column and see what you need to see. It takes time, but you don't have to trust a stranger's wordâ€”or pay for it.
A traveling merchant offers information about the road aheadâ€”bandits, broken bridges, enemy patrols. Useful knowledge, but he wants coin for it.
Road Ahead
Make a quick purchase
You hand over coin and take the goods. The quality is decentâ€”useful supplies that will serve you well on the road ahead.
Haggle for a better deal
'Half that,' you say, already turning away. 'Fine, fine!' the merchant yelps. A soldier who knows his prices is a rare thing.
A merchant catches you as the column forms. 'Wait, soldier! I have just what you needâ€”good price, won't find better on the road.' He waves a bundle of quality goods.
Last-Minute Purchase
Walk on without stopping

You shake your head and keep moving. The merchant shrugs and turns to the next soldier. Three days later, when supplies run low and prices double, you wonder if you made the right choice. But your coin is still yours.
Accept the loss and move on
Coin comes and goes. You've lost worse. You shoulder your pack and join the column, poorer but wiser.
Accuse a suspicious comrade
You confront the soldier you suspect. He denies it furiously, and others step in. Whether he's guilty or not, you've made an enemyâ€”and you're still short on coin.
Investigate before leaving
You retrace your steps and find the thiefâ€”a local cutpurse, still counting your coin. He drops everything and runs. Most of your money is recovered.
As you pack your gear, you realize your coin purse is lighter than it should be. Someone helped themselves while you sleptâ€”or while you drank.
Something's Missing
Help hide them better
You shift some crates to provide better cover and say nothing. Everyone deserves a second chance. Or maybe you just remember what desperation feels like.
Pretend you didn't see anything
You look away and keep walking. Not your problem, not your concern. Whatever happens, you didn't see a thing.
You spot movement in one of the supply wagonsâ€”someone is hiding, trying to leave town with the company. A runaway, perhaps, or a criminal fleeing justice.
The Stowaway
Turn them in to the officers
You drag the stowaway out and call for the sergeant. The wagon is searched, the intruder ejected. Proper procedure, by the book.
Leave it be
You step over the body and move on. Some things aren't worth the riskâ€”or the guilt.
Report the find to an officer
An officer nods and pockets the purse himself. He slips you a few coins for your honesty. 'Good soldier,' he mutters.
The battle is over. Bodies are scattered across the field. You notice a glint of gold on a corpse near your feetâ€”someone's purse, spilled open. Officers aren't looking this way. No one would know.
Take the gold
You pocket the coins quickly, glancing around. No one saw. The weight feels heavier than it should.
Dead Man's Purse
Deflect praise to the squad
'We all did our part, sir. The men beside me earned this recognition as much as I did.' The soldiers grin. The captain looks thoughtful.
Accept humbly
'Just doing my duty, sir.' The captain nods approvingly. Some of the men exchange glancesâ€”respect, maybe, or jealousy.
Accept with pride
'Thank you, sir. I've trained hard for moments like this.' The captain smiles slightly. The other soldiers are less impressed with your ego.
As you clean your blade, the captain approaches. 'You fought well today,' he says, loud enough for others to hear. Men are watching. Public recognition from an officer is rare.
The Captain's Eye
Public flogging. Make an example.
He takes the lashes without a sound. The men watch in silence. They won't run. But they won't love you for this.
Remove him from your retinue. Send him back to the main force.
He's reassigned. Your men nod approval. You don't tolerate cowardice, but you're not cruel about it.
Let it go. Everyone has a bad day.
You say nothing. The men exchange glances. If running is acceptable, what else is? Your authority weakens.

One of your men ran. You saw it during the fightingâ€”turned and fled while the rest held the line. Now the battle is over and he's back, trying to blend in with the others.
Your sergeant is waiting for your order. The men are watching.
The Coward
Talk to him privately. Find out why.
He breaks down. First battle. Saw his brother die in the last war. You assign him to the rear for now. The men respect that you listened.
Count the losses. Remember the names.
You go through the list. Every man lost, every name. Your soldiers watch you do it. They know you'll remember them too.
Rally your men. Show strength.
You walk among them, checking wounds, offering words. They see you as their commander now. Not just a promoted soldier.
Take a moment. Process what just happened.
You breathe. Think. Remember the mistakes and the successes. Command is weight. You'll carry it better next time.

Your first battle as a commander is over. You led men into the fight. Some followed your orders perfectly. Some hesitated. Some didn't come back.
You're standing alone now, watching your soldiers tend their wounds. This is what command feels like.
First Command
Look the other way. Let them have it.
You turn and walk away. Your men grin and keep working. They'll remember this. So might the officers, if they notice.
Help them. Take a share for yourself.
You kneel down and start searching bodies with them. They laugh. You're one of them now. Command just got more complicated.

The fighting just ended. Bodies are still warm. You find some of your men already rifling through enemy packs, pocketing valuables.
Looting rights haven't been called yet. Technically, this is theft from the army's share. But soldiers have always done this. The question is whether you stop it.
Stop them. Order them back to formation.
They grumble but comply. You're following regulations. Your men think you're a stickler. The officers think you're reliable.
Early Looters
Let your man have his revenge.
Your soldier draws his blade. It's over quickly. The prisoner dies cursing you. Your men nod approval. You've chosen their side.
Ask your men to vote. Their call.
You put it to them. They argue. Eventually they vote to spare him for the ransom. Your soldier accepts it, barely. You've shown you trust their judgment.

Your men have captured an enemy officer. He's wounded, disarmed, and begging for his life. Says he has a family. Offers ransom.
One of your soldiersâ€”a veteranâ€”spits at him. "His kind killed my brother. Let me finish him."
Your decision. Your responsibility.
Take him prisoner. He's worth more alive.
You order him bound and sent to the rear. Your soldier glares at you. The prisoner thanks you. Gold is gold, but this cost you something.
The Prisoner's Plea
"Thank you, my lord. We did our duty."
Your lord nods, satisfied. Your men appreciate the humility. You're a commander, but you're not arrogant about it.
"We held because I trained them well, my lord."
Your lord's smile fades. Your men shift uncomfortably. You just took all the credit. That's not how you build loyalty.
"The credit belongs to my men, my lord. They're the ones who bled."
Your men exchange glances. You just gave them the glory. They'll remember this. Your lord smiles slightlyâ€”good leadership.

The battle is won. Your lord rides up, surveying the field. He sees you with your men and nods.
"Your retinue fought well, Commander. They held the flank when others wavered. I'm pleased."
Your men straighten up, hearing this. How you respond matters.
There's nothing you can do. Move on.
You stand and walk away. His eyes follow you until they don't. Your men exchange looks. They understand. They don't like it.

The battle is over. As you count heads, you find one of your men lying in the mud, gut wound, bleeding out. He recognizes you. Tries to speak. The surgeon is already overwhelmed with critical cases.
Your men are watching. Waiting to see what you do.
Stay with him until the end
You kneel beside him. Hold his hand. He dies quietly, knowing he wasn't alone. Your men see this. They remember.
Demand the surgeon treat him now
The surgeon scowls but complies. Your man survives, barely. The surgeon won't forget this.
One of Your Own
Drink and try to forget

The wine doesn't make the fear go away, but it blurs the edges. You drink with the men who might not see tomorrow, sharing stories and lies in equal measure. When dawn comes, your hands shakeâ€”from drink or terror, who can tell?
Prepare your equipment carefully
You check every strap, sharpen every edge, and test every buckle. When dawn comes, you're as ready as any man can be.
Rally the men with words
You speak of honor, of home, of the dawn to come. The men listen. Some nod, some weep, but all of them seem steadier when you finish.
Tomorrow, the walls. Ladders are being prepared, siege towers wheeled into position. Tonight, men pray, drink, or simply stare at the fires. What do you do on what might be your last night?
Before the Assault
Enforce strict discipline
You crack down on idleness. Drills, patrols, pointless work detailsâ€”anything to keep the men occupied. They grumble, but they stop fighting each other.
Organize games and competitions
Wrestling, races, archery contestsâ€”you give the men something to do besides brood. Morale lifts, if only for a while.
Let the men sort it out themselves
You stay out of it. Men will be men. A few black eyes and bureaucratic egos won't change the course of the siege.
Weeks of waiting have worn the men thin. Fights break out over nothing. Dice games turn sour. The walls don't fall, and neither does the boredom.
Siege Tedium
Confront him yourself
'Where do you think you're going?' He freezes, terrified. You talk him down, and he creeps back to his tent. No one else needs to know.
Let him go
You pretend not to see. Maybe he has a family, maybe he's just afraid. Either way, it's not your place to judge. The darkness swallows him.
Report him to the watch
You raise the alarm quietly. Guards intercept the deserter before he reaches the walls. His fate is sealedâ€”but you did your duty.
Late at night, you spot movement near the perimeter. Someone is creeping toward the enemy linesâ€”a deserter, slipping away under cover of darkness. You could stop him, or let him go.
Watching the Walls
Stay as far from the sick as possible
You keep your distance, sleeping far from the infected tents. Cowardly, perhaps, but you remain healthy while others fall.
Pray for divine intervention
You join the prayers. It brings comfort, if not healing. Some men die with peace in their hearts, at least.
Enforce strict quarantine
Working with the surgeon, you isolate the sick and burn the infected bedding. It's brutal, but the spread slows. Lives are saved.
Men are dying in their tents, not from enemy arrows but from disease. The surgeon is overwhelmed, and the burial details can't keep up. The siege may fail not to swords, but to sickness.
The Plague
Break up the game
'That's enough for tonight.' Your authority ends the game before blood is shed. Some men thank you later; others don't.
Join the game
You take a seat and throw the dice. Fortune favors you tonightâ€”the other players grumble as you rake in your winnings.
Report it to the officers
The sergeant arrives and scatters the game. Coin is confiscated, men are disciplined. You're not popular for it.
The dice games have gotten serious. Men are betting their pay, their equipment, even their rations. Tempers are rising, and the stakes keep climbing.
Siege Gambling
Lead a small party to exploit it
You gather a handful of volunteers and slip forward in the night. The weak point crumbles under your assault, and you're the first through the gap.
Report it to the engineers
You bring your observation to the siege master. He squints at the wall, nods slowly, and orders sappers to concentrate there. 'Good eye, soldier.'
Keep the knowledge to yourself

You say nothing. Secrets have value, and this one might be worth something somedayâ€”leverage with the right officer, or an escape route if things go badly. You file it away with all the other things you've learned not to share.
You notice something the officers missedâ€”a section of wall where the mortar is crumbling, where a determined assault might break through. Valuable intelligence, if you share it.
Wall Weakness
Keep your distance and hope for the best
You stay as far from the sick tents as possible. Self-preservation isn't noble, but you're still healthy when others aren't.
Investigate the cause
You trace the sickness to a contaminated water source. With the surgeon's help, you identify the problem and warn the officers. The outbreak slows.
Help enforce a quarantine
You help separate the sick from the healthy. It's grim workâ€”many don't come back from the fever tentsâ€”but it stops the spread.

Sickness is spreading through the siege camp. Men cough in their tents, and the latrines overflow with the afflicted. The source could be the water, the food, or just too many men in too small a space.
Camp Fever
Half the provisions have gone badâ€”worms in the grain, mold on the meat. Men are getting sick from eating what's left, but there's nothing else. The siege has gone on too long.
Spoiled Rations
Lead a foraging party
You slip out of camp and scour the countryside. A village, overlooked by other foragers, provides enough food to supplement the rotting stores.
Inform the officers and let them decide
You bring the problem to the captain. He looks grim but makes no decisions. The spoiled food is issued anyway. Men get sick.
Ration the remaining good food carefully
You help the quartermaster sort through the stores, separating the edible from the rotten. Portions are small, but at least they're safe.
Demand a cut to stay quiet
You confront the thief privately. 'Share or I talk.' He agrees, and now you're eating better than mostâ€”and just as guilty.
Investigate the thefts
You watch and wait. When the thief makes his move, you catch him red-handed. The quartermaster is grateful for your vigilance.
Report your suspicions to the officers
You tell the quartermaster what you've noticed. He promises to increase the guard. The thefts slow, but don't stop entirely.
Food is disappearing from the company stores. Someone is stealing rationsâ€”either hoarding for themselves or selling on the black market. Hungry men are getting suspicious.
Missing Supplies
Search for another water source
You slip away and search the siege works. A spring, missed by others, trickles from the rocks. You mark the spot and report it to the sergeant.
Keep what's yours
You guard your water jealously. Survival comes firstâ€”there's no room for sentiment when the wells run dry.
The wells are running low, and the sun beats down without mercy. Men queue for their water ration, lips cracked and eyes hollow. You notice a soldier with more than his share.
Share your ration with someone weaker
You press your waterskin into a suffering soldier's hands. He drinks gratefully, and others see what you did. It costs you, but it matters.
Water Rations
Walk away and let it happen
You turn your back. What happens behind you is not your responsibility. The sounds fade quickly. War is ugly.
Protect the prisoners
'They surrendered. That means they're prisoners, not targets.' Your voice carries weight. The angry soldiers back off, and the prisoners are taken to the officers.

A handful of enemy soldiers have surrenderedâ€”wounded, exhausted, and terrified. They sit in the mud, hands raised. Some of your comrades are eyeing them with dark intent. What happens next is up to those who have swords.
Ensure their silence permanently
You step forward and do what needs doing. Quick, efficient, final. The men watch without comment. This is the reality of war.
The Survivors
Try to defuse the situation
'Easy, friends. We're all just here for a drink.' Your calm voice cuts through the tension. The locals back off, and the evening continues peacefully.
Fight back
Fists fly and furniture breaks. You take some hits but give better than you get. When it's over, you're bloody but standing.
Slip away before it gets worse
You're not drunk enough to fight for nothing. You slip out the back door and let the fools sort themselves out.
Local men don't like soldiers. Words become shoves, shoves become fists. A brawl is starting, and you're in the middle of it.
Tavern Trouble
Hear him out
Smuggling, he says. Move a package, ask no questions, get paid well. Risky, but the money is real.
Refuse and walk away
'Not interested.' The figure shrugs and melts back into the shadows. A wise choice, or a missed opportunityâ€”hard to say.
Report him to the town guard
You point out the criminal to a passing patrol. They chase him into the alleys. Whether they catch him, you don't knowâ€”but you did your duty.
A figure in the shadows knows your face. 'You're with the company,' he whispers. 'I have an offer. Good coin for a simple job. Interested?'
Criminal Contact
Spread false information
You casually mention invented troop movements and supply routes. If these rumors spread to the enemy, they'll be chasing shadows.
Join the conversation
You pull up a chair and share a few war stories. The locals warm to you, and the conversation flows more freely. Useful details emerge.
Listen carefully without joining
You nurse your drink and let the talk wash over you. Most of it is nonsense, but a few details might be worth remembering.
The locals are talking about the warâ€”troop movements, supply problems, rumors of battles. Some of it sounds useful. You could listen carefully, or join the conversation.
Town Gossip
Buy what looks useful
You hand over coin and walk away with quality goods. Maybe stolen, maybe not. Either way, they're yours now.
Haggle for a better price
'Half that,' you say flatly. The merchant grumbles but accepts. A soldier who knows his pricesâ€”rare enough to respect.
A trader in the market catches your eye. He has goods at suspiciously good pricesâ€”weapons, armor, supplies. 'Fell off a wagon,' he says with a wink. Maybe legitimate salvage, maybe stolen.
Merchant's Offer
Walk away, it's not worth the risk
You shake your head and move on. Too many questions about where those goods came from. Best not to invite trouble.
Burn it unread
You toss it into the nearest fire without breaking the seal. That life is gone. No point in looking back.
Save it for later
You slip the letter into your pack, unopened. Some things are better saved for when you need them most.
Read it immediately
The words bring comfort and pain in equal measure. Home feels both close and impossibly far. You fold the letter carefully and tuck it away.
The innkeeper hands you a sealed letter. 'Been waiting for you,' he says. Your name is written in familiar handwriting. A message from your old life, from before you took the king's coin.
Message from Home
Approach and reconnect
You tap their shoulder. The recognition, the smile, the embraceâ€”for a moment, you're not a soldier, you're just yourself again.
Avoid them and move on
You pull your hood lower and take another route. That life is gone. No point reopening old wounds.
Watch from a distance first
You linger in the shadows, watching. They seem well, happy even. Maybe that's enough. You slip away without approaching.
Someone from your past is hereâ€”a childhood friend, a former comrade, perhaps someone you'd rather forget. They haven't seen you yet. This could be a reunion or a complication.
Familiar Face
Consider the offer seriously
You listen to the pitch. It's temptingâ€”better conditions, honest pay. But changing masters isn't simple. You take his name, just in case.
Hear them out but commit to nothing

You listen politely, ask questions, and make no promises. The recruiter shares details about his employerâ€”troop strength, pay rates, current campaigns. Information is useful, even if you never act on it. And information has value to those who know how to use it.
Refuse firmly
'I have a lord. Find someone else.' The recruiter nods and moves on. Loyalty has its price, but also its value.
A well-dressed man approaches. 'You look like a soldier with experience,' he says. 'My employer is hiringâ€”better pay, less risk, more freedom. Think about it.'
Recruitment Pitch
Drink deep and forget the war

The night blurs into warmth and laughter. You buy rounds, tell stories that grow taller with each cup, and for a few hours you're not a soldierâ€”just a man enjoying life. You wake with a pounding head, lighter coin, and a vague memory of arm-wrestling the sergeant. Worth it.
Have a few drinks, keep your wits
You share stories with the soldiers, laugh at old jokes, and keep your coin purse close. A good evening, nothing more.
You have a few hours of freedom in town. The tavern beckonsâ€”warm lights, loud voices, the smell of ale and roasted meat. A drink wouldn't hurt. Or maybe it would.
Stay sober and keep watch
You nurse a single cup of ale for hours, watching the others. Someone needs to stay sharp. The men notice your discipline.
The Tavern
Carry the wounded to safety
You can't heal, but you can lift. You haul wounded men to the surgeon's tent until your arms burn. Lives are saved because you were strong enough.
Help with the wounded
You kneel in the blood and mud, doing what you can. Some you save. Some you can't. The surgeon nods at you when it's overâ€”the highest praise he ever gives.
Move on, it's not your duty
You pretend not to hear and keep walking. The surgeon's stare follows you. Some things are someone else's problem.
Wounded are screaming across the field. The surgeon is overwhelmed, moving from body to body. He sees you and calls outâ€”another pair of hands could save lives.
Call for Medics
Accept their hospitality with thanks

You take the bread and cheese with genuine gratitude. The elder's wife presses a wrapped package into your handsâ€”extra provisions for the road. 'For a kind soldier,' she says. Simple kindness goes a long way.
Politely decline, they need it more
You wave off the food. 'Save it for your children,' you say. The elder nods with respect, and the villagers whisper among themselves.
Demand more provisions as tribute

The elder's face falls, but he complies. You take extra food, coin, and whatever else catches your eye. A child cries as you pocket her mother's bread. Your comrades watch in silence. Some things can't be taken back.

The villagers greet the company with relief and gratitude. They've been raided before, and your lord's banner means protection. An elder offers bread and cheese to the soldiers. Simple fare, but freely given.
Village Welcome
Tell him the truth about soldier life
You describe the mud, the blood, the friends you've buried. His enthusiasm fades. 'Stay home,' you say. 'There's nothing glorious about dying in a ditch.'
Encourage his dreams
You tell him where to find the recruiting sergeant. His face lights up with joy. His mother's face crumbles with grief. War needs bodies.
Let him make his own choice

'It's your life,' you say. 'Think carefully before you throw it away.' His mother catches your eye as you passâ€”a look of gratitude mixed with fear. You gave him neither hope nor despair. Perhaps that's wisdom.

A young villager approaches, eyes bright with foolish dreams. 'Take me with you,' he begs. 'I want to be a soldier, fight for the lord, see the world.' His mother watches from a doorway, fear in her face.
Eager Youth
Demand the respect soldiers deserve
You bang on a door and demand hospitality. The villager complies, but hatred burns in his eyes. You've made enemies here.
Leave quickly, this place isn't safe
You urge the company to move on. Some places aren't worth the trouble. The village disappears behind you, and good riddance.
Be polite and give them space
You keep your distance, speak softly, and cause no trouble. By the time you leave, a few villagers nod in grudging respect.
These people don't want soldiers here. Doors close as you approach, and eyes watch from behind shuttered windows. The last army that came through took more than it protected.
Cold Reception
Dismiss it as peasant gossip
You shrug and walk on. Old women see ghosts in every shadow. Later, you hear the captain cursing about an ambush that could have been avoided. Probably unrelated. Probably.
Investigate the area they described
You slip away and scout the eastern road. Fresh tracks, many horses, heading north. The rumors were true. You report back with valuable information.
Listen carefully and gather details
You ask careful questions. Numbers, banners, direction of travelâ€”the old women know more than they realize. This could be valuable intelligence.
Old women talk by the well. They've seen troops moving to the east, they say. Soldiers with strange banners, riding hard. The kind of gossip that wins battlesâ€”or loses them.
Village Rumors
Apologize, you can't help
You shake your head sadly. 'I'm a soldier, not a healer.' She turns away, hope fading from her eyes. There's nothing more you can do.
Give her your healing supplies
You press your own medicines into her hands. 'These might help,' you say. Her gratitude is overwhelming, though you'll miss those supplies later.
Try to help with your medical knowledge
You examine the child and recognize the fever. Willow bark tea and cool clothsâ€”simple remedies, but they work. The mother weeps with relief.
A villager begs for help. Her child is fevered, burning up. The local healer is dead, gone in the last raid. She clutches your arm with desperate strength.
The Sick Child
Look away and pretend you didn't see
You turn your head and keep walking. It's not your problem. The soldier relaxes and pockets his prize. These things happen.
Intervene and make him return it
'Put it back.' Your voice is quiet but firm. He hesitates, then complies. The villager never knows how close she came to losing her meal.
Report him to the sergeant
You find the sergeant and explain what you saw. The thief is disciplinedâ€”flogged, probably. He won't forget who reported him.
You see it happenâ€”a soldier from your company, taking food from a villager's basket while she isn't looking. He catches your eye and freezes, stolen bread in hand.
Caught Stealing
Find something useful to do
You organize equipment maintenance, run impromptu drills, or find work that needs doing. It's not exciting, but it keeps hands busy and minds occupied.
Crack down on troublemakers
You single out the worst offenders and make examples of them. The grumbling stops, replaced by sullen obedience. Order is maintained.
Let the men sort themselves out
You stay out of it. Soldiers will be soldiers. A few black eyes and bureaucratic egos won't hurt the company. Probably.
Another day of nothing. The men are getting antsyâ€”dice games turning sour, tempers fraying, petty disputes festering. Garrison duty is wearing on everyone.
Garrison Tedium
Avoid them entirely

You slip away before they notice you. Later, you hear the men talking about the fascinating strangerâ€”tales of distant lands, news of the war, predictions that proved true. You missed something. Whether it mattered, you'll never know.
Engage them in conversation
You share stories and learn something new. The world is larger than battlefields and barracks. A pleasant reminder.
Watch and listen from a distance
You keep your distance but pay attention. Interesting bits of information, useful detailsâ€”a soldier learns to gather intelligence everywhere.
Someone interesting crosses your path while you wait. A traveling scholar with strange tales, a veteran soldier with battle wisdom, or a mysterious stranger who knows more than they should.
Chance Encounter
Investigate before committing
You ask questions and check details. The job is legitimateâ€”low risk, decent pay. You take it with confidence.
Pass on it, duty comes first
You shake your head. 'I'm on duty.' The opportunity passes to someone else. Maybe that's for the best.
Garrison duty is dull, but it creates opportunities. A merchant needs guards for a quick job. A local lord is hiring for a private matter. Something to break the tediumâ€”and maybe fill your purse.
Take the opportunity
You slip away for a few hours and earn some extra coin. The job is simple enough, and you're back before anyone notices you were gone.
Passing Opportunity
You sense something about to go wrong. Angry locals gathering in a square. Soldiers drinking too much and getting rowdy. A confrontation forming that could turn ugly.
Trouble Brewing
Mind your own business
You look away and let events unfold. Whatever happens, it's not your responsibility. The garrison watch will sort it out.
Prepare for when it goes wrong
You position yourself near the exit and loosen your blade. When the brawl erupts, you're ready. Sometimes the best move is being prepared to move.
Try to prevent the trouble
You step in before fists fly. A firm voice, a steady presenceâ€”the situation defuses. Some will thank you; others will call you a busybody.
Call for a medic
You signal for the surgeon's assistant. He looks at you oddly but comes over. 'Strange to waste bandages on them,' he says, but he does it anyway.
End his suffering
You draw your blade and finish it quickly. Mercy or crueltyâ€”you're not sure which. The field is quieter now.
A wounded enemy soldier lies in the mud, blood pooling beneath him. He's watching you, eyes wide with fear and pain. He's not dead yet. No one else is around.
Leave him to his fate
You walk away. His labored breathing fades behind you. He might live, he might not. That's not your decision to make.
The Wounded Enemy
Soldiers Fighting
Two soldiers are throwing punches behind the supply tents. Blood's already been drawn.
Break it up yourself.
You pull them apart. Both men are breathing hard but the fight's over.
You catch an elbow to the face pulling them apart. Fight's over though.
Get {SERGEANT}.
{SERGEANT} arrives and sorts them out. Both men glare at you.
Let them settle it.
One man goes down. The other walks off. Not your problem.
Gambling Ring
Behind the tents, a group of soldiers are rolling dice. Coins glint in the firelight. They freeze when they see you.
Break it up. Gambling's against regulations.
They scatter, grumbling. You've made no friends tonight.
Join in for a few rounds.
Luck's with you tonight. You walk away with heavier pockets.
The dice hate you. You're lighter in the purse but richer in friends.
Walk past. You saw nothing.
They nod gratefully as you pass. What gambling?
Suspicious Activity
A figure moves between tents at the edge of camp. Something's not right about the way they're moving.
Investigate quietly.
Just a soldier sneaking back from the latrine. False alarm.
You stumble over a tent rope. The figure vanishes. Nothing found.
Report to {SERGEANT} immediately.
{SERGEANT} sends men to check. Nothing found, but you followed procedure.
Probably nothing. Keep walking.
You continue your rounds. Hopefully it was nothing.
Rough Ground
The ground here is uneven and dark. Your ankle twists on a hidden rut. Pain shoots up your leg.
Push through the pain.
You walk it off. Hurts, but you finish your patrol.
You make it worse. Limping through the rest of your shift.
Rest for a moment.
A few minutes off your feet helps. You continue more carefully.
Report the injury.
{SERGEANT} sends someone to finish your patrol. You're off duty.
Lost Item
A soldier approaches you, worried. He's lost something valuableâ€”a ring from his wife. Asks if you've seen it.
Help him search.
You spot it glinting near the fire pit. His gratitude is genuine.
No luck, but he appreciates the effort.
Not your problem. Keep patrolling.
He looks disappointed as you walk away.
You found it earlier. Keep it.
The ring's worth something. He'll never know.
You know a shortcut that would skip two checkpoints. No one would know. Your feet ache.
Take the shortcut.
You cut through. {SERGEANT} was watching. You're in trouble.
Do the full route. Orders are orders.
You complete every checkpoint. Your feet hurt, but your conscience is clear.
Damaged Equipment
While cleaning equipment, you find damage that someone tried to hide. A sword with a crack in the blade, poorly concealed.
Report it to the quartermaster.
The quartermaster logs it. Someone's in for an awkward conversation.
Try to repair it quietly.
With some work, you manage a field repair. The owner owes you.
You make it worse. Now it's obvious someone tried to hide it.
Not your problem. Put it back.
You set it aside and continue. Someone else can deal with it.
Struggling Comrade
A new recruit is struggling with his gear, obviously overwhelmed by the amount of leather that needs oiling.
Show him how it's done.
He watches gratefully as you demonstrate. The work goes faster together.
Let him figure it out.
You focus on your own gear. He'll learn eventually.
Mock his inexperience.
The veterans laugh. He turns red but keeps working. Made an enemy today.
Point out the work you struggled with.
He nods. 'Honesty is good. Keep working on it.'
Present your work confidently.
He finds a spot you missed. 'Sloppy. Do it again.'
He examines a blade, nods. 'Fine work, soldier.'
{OFFICER_NAME} walks through, checking the work. He stops at your station.
Charge through! Don't stop!
You whip the horses forward. Speed saves more than it costs.
Circle the wagons! Defensive formation!
Chaos. Men die before you restore order. But you hold.
You rally the men. The wagons form a wall. You hold until they withdraw.
Sacrifice the rear wagon. Save the rest.
The rear guard buys time with their lives. The convoy escapes.
Arrows from the trees! Men fall. The convoy is under attack.
Form defensive stance.
They attack anyway. You hold, but take casualties.
You circle the wagons. They probe once, see your readiness, and withdraw.
Ride out to parley.
A 'toll' for safe passage. Cheaper than blood.
Riders on the ridge. They're watching the convoy. Too many to be travelers.
Speed up. Outrun them.
You push the pace. They follow for a while, then fall back.
Bandits Spotted
Accept the deal.
He tells you where to dig. The gold is real. So is your guilt.
Refuse. You have your orders.
'Your loss,' he mutters. You deliver him as ordered.
Report his bribe attempt.
{SERGEANT} nods. 'Good man. We'll find that gold ourselves.'
One of the prisoners catches your eye. 'I have gold hidden. Let me go, and it's yours.'
Prisoner's Offer
A narrow pass could save half a day. But it's perfect ambush territory.
Take the long way. Safety first.
The extra miles are worth the peace of mind. You arrive intact.
Take the shortcut.
Ambush in the narrows. You fight through, but pay in blood.
You scout ahead, move fast. The pass is clear. Time saved.
Risky Shortcut
Comply with his wishes.
You take his route. It's not faster, but he's satisfied.
Explain why you can't.
He's not convinced, but you're in charge. He sulks the rest of the way.
He listens to reason. Grudgingly, he accepts your judgment.
Refuse flatly. You have orders.
'I answer to {LORD_NAME}, not you.' He's furious, but you're right.
The noble you're escorting demands you take a different route. 'I know a faster way.'
VIP Demands
Find a way around.
You scout ahead and find firmer ground. The convoy detours safely.
Lighten the load first.
You unload crates. The wagon pulls free. Some supplies stay behind.
Everyone push. Brute force.
It takes three tries, but you get it moving.
Shoulders to the wheel. It lurches free with a sucking sound.
The lead wagon's wheel sinks deep in the mud. The convoy grinds to a halt.
Stuck Wagon
Ignore it. Keep chopping.
Blood drips down the axe handle. You finish, but the wound looks angry.
Wrap it and keep working.
The cut's deeper than you thought. Blood soaks through the bandage.
You bind it tight. Hurts, but you finish the job.
Report to the surgeon.
The surgeon cleans and binds it properly. You're back to work soon.
The axe slips. Blood wells from your hand. Not deep, but it stings.
Axe Slip
Accept the challenge.
Close, but {COMRADE_NAME} edges you out. Good sport though.
You win by two logs. {COMRADE_NAME} buys the drinks tonight.
Decline. Save your energy.
He shrugs and finds another challenger.
Accept, but raise the stakes.
You lose, and your coin with it. At least you tried.
You win, and his coin. The men cheer.
{COMRADE_NAME} challenges you to a chopping contest. First to split ten logs wins.
Open it carefully and examine contents.
Old coins and a map. {SERGEANT} rewards your thoroughness.
Pocket what's inside.
A few coins. Not much, but it's yours now.
Report it to {SERGEANT}.
{SERGEANT} takes it for the company. You did the right thing.
Digging out a stump, your shovel hits something metal. A small chest, half-buried.
Found Something
Circle around quietly.
You give it wide berth. It never notices you.
Kill it. Fresh meat for the company.
It gores your leg before you bring it down. Worth it for the meat.
One clean strike. Tonight, the company eats well.
A boar crashes through the underbrush. It's big, angry, and between you and camp.
Shout a warning to the others.
Everyone backs off. The boar snorts and moves on.
Join in.
Your voice joins the chorus. The work goes faster.
Start a different songâ€”a better one.
The men pick up your tune. Soon the whole detail is singing.
{COMRADE_NAME} starts a work song. The rhythm helps the axes fall in time.
Keep working in silence.
You focus on the work. The song continues without you.
Work Song
Find a defensible position and forage from there.
You set up a base and work the area systematically. Good haul.
Move carefully. Stay hidden.
Spotted. You run for it. Arrows bite your back.
You slip through like ghosts. Small haul, but safe return.
You're far from friendly lines. Every shadow could hide an enemy patrol.
Speed is safety. Grab and go.
In and out. Fast work. You're back before anyone notices.
Deep in Enemy Land
Remind him who has the swords.
He backs down. You take what you need. His eyes follow you all the way.
Leave empty-handed. Not worth the trouble.
You walk away. One less enemy. The company will find food elsewhere.
Pay him a fair price.
He drives a hard bargain. You pay more than you wanted.
He takes your coin and helps you load the cart. Fair dealing.
A farmer blocks your path, pitchfork in hand. 'You're not taking my grain without paying.'
Farmer Encounter
Leave coins for the farmer.
You leave silver on the table. Soldiers aren't always thieves.
You find a barn, half-hidden in the trees. Inside: grain, smoked meat, preserved vegetables. A fortune in supplies.
Take everything. Leave nothing for the enemy.
You strip it bare. Scorched earth. Effective, but hard on the locals.
Take what the company needs. Leave the rest.
You load the essentials and move on. Professional.
Well-Stocked Barn
Call out. Hope they hear you.
A whistle answers. You follow the sound back to your group.
Find your own way back.
You blunder into trouble. A patrol finds youâ€”ours, thankfully.
You track back by sun and landmarks. You find camp on your own.
You wandered too far. The others are nowhere in sight. The trees all look the same.
Stay put. Let them find you.
You wait. Within the hour, {COMRADE_NAME} appears through the brush.
Leave it all. Not worth getting sick.
You walk away. Hungry beats poisoned.
Mark the location for a proper recovery team.
You note the landmarks. A team with wagons can salvage the rest.
You find an old supply cache. Half of it's rotting. The smell hits you from ten paces.
Take what's still good. Risk the bad stuff.
You sort carefully. Most of it's edible. Probably.
Spoiled Cache
Back away slowly. Not worth the fight.
It snorts and crashes off. You're not here for hunting.
Hunt it. Fresh meat for the company.
It catches you with a tusk. Blood everywhere. You get the beast eventually.
A clean kill. The men will eat well tonight.
Make noise. Scare it away.
You shout and wave. It hesitates, then retreats. Close call.
A boar bursts from the underbrush. Big, tusked, and angry. You're between it and its territory.
Dangerous Animal
Go find your relief.
You find {COMRADE_NAME} asleep. He rushes to the post.
Leave your post. You've done your time.
{SERGEANT} finds the post unmanned. You're in serious trouble.
Your shift ended an hour ago. No relief has arrived. You're exhausted.
Stay at your post until relief arrives.
Two more hours pass before {COMRADE_NAME} arrives. {SERGEANT} notes your dedication.
No Relief
Let him through. Not worth the trouble.
He staggers past. You hope {SERGEANT} doesn't find out.
Report him to {SERGEANT}.
{SERGEANT} hauls him away. The other soldiers give you cold looks.
A drunk soldier stumbles toward your post, demanding to pass. {SERGEANT} told you no one passes without authorization.
Drunk Soldier
Turn him away. Orders are orders.
He curses you but stumbles off. You held your post.
Politely insist on proper authorization.
He storms off angry. You held your post, but he'll complain.
He's annoyed but respects your duty. {SERGEANT} approves.
Fetch {OFFICER_NAME} to handle this.
{OFFICER_NAME} handles it. You followed procedure.
Let him through. He's a noble.
He passes. {SERGEANT} later asks why you broke protocol.
A well-dressed noble demands entry without proper authorization. He's clearly used to getting his way.
Noble Without Papers
Challenge him properly.
He smiles. 'Good work, {PLAYER_RANK}. You know your duty.'
Hesitate, unsure what to do.
Your hesitation shows. He walks past shaking his head.
Let him pass without challenge.
He stops. 'You failed the test, soldier. Challenge everyone.'
An officer approaches your post in the night. He's not wearing his insignia. This could be a test.
Officer Inspection
Accept the relief and rest.
You head back to your tent. A welcome break.
Offer to stay and finish your shift.
{COMRADE_NAME} appreciates it. You finish your full shift.
Your relief arrives an hour early. {COMRADE_NAME} says {SERGEANT} changed the schedule.
Early Relief
Hold your post and watch.
The noise fades. You stay alert.
Investigate the noise.
You trip in the dark and bash your shin. Nothing there.
You find a stray dog. Better safe than sorry.
Raise the alarm.
The camp wakes. Nothing found. {SERGEANT} is not pleased.
You hear a strange noise in the darkness beyond your post. Could be nothing. Could be trouble.
Strange Noise
Delegate the repair to the garrison crew.
You mark the spot and find the work crew. They'll handle it. You move on.
Fix it yourself. Organize a repair.
Your repair holds, but it's not pretty. Someone will need to finish it properly.
You gather men and materials. By evening, the section is solid. Better than before.
Report to {OFFICER_NAME} immediately.
{OFFICER_NAME} sends a work crew within the hour. 'Good eye, soldier.'
The palisade looks solid until you press on it. The post gives. Rotten at the base. This section would collapse under assault.
Structural Flaw
Keep it to yourself. Not your place to suggest.
You note it and move on. Maybe someone else will see it too.
Propose it formally to the officers.
They listen but aren't convinced. Maybe another time.
You present your idea to the council. They're impressed. Work begins within the week.
Looking at the fortifications, you see a way to improve them. A simple change that would double the defensive strength of this section.
Mention it quietly to {SERGEANT}.
{SERGEANT} nods slowly. 'Not bad. I'll mention it to the captain.' Credit may or may not come your way.
Better Design
Offer a compromise. Split the resources.
Your compromise pleases no one. But at least they've stopped arguing.
You suggest splitting the work crew. Both officers nod. Diplomacy wins.
Two officers are arguing over repair priorities. The senior wants the gate reinforced; the junior insists the walls are more critical. They turn to you.
Support the junior's assessment.
You side with the junior. The senior glares, but the walls do need work.
Support the senior officer.
You back the senior. Chain of command. The junior fumes but accepts it.
Conflicting Orders
Investigate quietly. Find who did this.
A tripwire. The saboteur left a surprise. You're lucky it wasn't worse.
You follow the trail. It leads to footprints near the postern gate. Someone's getting in and out.
Report to {OFFICER_NAME} immediately.
The officer takes charge. Guards are doubled. The investigation begins.
Set a watch. Catch them in the act.
You position watchers and wait. If they come back, you'll be ready.
The damage here isn't from weather or age. Someone cut these ropes. Deliberately. Recently.
Signs of Sabotage
Apologize and promise to do better.
He grunts and walks away. You continue as before.
It's a latrine, sir. How clean can it be?
His eyes narrow. 'You just earned another day of this duty, soldier.'
Yes sir. Redo the work.
You scrub until it meets his standards. He nods curtly and leaves.
An officer wrinkles his nose. 'This is unacceptable, soldier. Do it again. Properly this time.'
Officer Complaint
Cough loudly to alert them.
They glance your way and lower their voices. Conversation moves elsewhere.
Mind your own business.
You focus on your work. Whatever they're discussing isn't your concern.
Listen carefully.
You catch fragments. Useful information, if anyone asks.
Two officers pass nearby, deep in conversation. They don't notice you working. Something about troop movements.
Overheard Conversation
Accept the thanks graciously.
He claps you on the shoulder and moves on. Small kindnesses matter.
Brush it off. Just doing your duty.
He nods and leaves. Back to work.
A soldier stops by. 'Someone's got to do it. Thanks for keeping things decent around here.'
Unexpected Thanks
Charge through! Break the ambush!
You scream and charge. The ambushers break. Costly, but you shattered them.
Fighting retreat! Fall back!
You fall back in order. Men covering each other. You escape the kill zone.
Rally defense! Form up!
Chaos. You rally what's left. Too many dead.
You shout orders. Men form a ring. The attackers break against your steel.
Arrows from the treeline! You've walked right into an ambush. Men are falling.
Set an ambush. Turn the tables.
They spot the trap. A messy fight follows.
They walk right into it. Quick and clean. Your men look at you with new respect.
Engage them.
They fight hard. You win, but too many of your men fall.
Steel and blood. You take them down, but not without cost.
Evade. Go around them.
You slip around their flank. Mission continues.
Enemy patrol spotted ahead. Eight men. They haven't seen you yet. Your call.
Enemy Contact
Investigate carefully. Could be a trap.
Trip wire. The explosion wounds you. Should have been more careful.
You check for traps first. It's clean. A proper haul.
Mark the location and report back.
You note the landmarks carefully. A recovery party can collect everything.
Secure the supplies and bring them back.
Some of it's spoiled. You take what's good.
Good find. The men load what they can carry. {LORD_NAME} will be pleased.
Your patrol spots somethingâ€”an abandoned supply cache. Enemy markings on the crates.
Valuable Find
Treat it in the field. Keep him moving.
Your field medicine isn't great. He's in pain, but still moving.
You bind it tight. He limps along, but he's with you.
Push on. He can manage.
He hobbles along, face tight with pain. The men are not pleased.
Send him back with an escort.
Two men head back with him. Your patrol is smaller, but unslowed.
{SOLDIER_NAME} twisted his ankle badly. He can barely walk. You're still deep in enemy territory.
Injured Man
Give them a reason to care.
The words come out flat. Some nod, most don't.
You remind them what they're fighting for. Backs straighten. Pace quickens.
Listen to their complaints.
You let them vent. Sometimes that's all men need.
The men are tired and starting to complain. 'Another patrol. What's the point?' Morale is slipping.
Remind them of the consequences of failure.
They shut up and march. Fear works, but it's not loyalty.
Grumbling Men
Hear him out, then decide.
You blend both ideas. A good leader listens.
Overrule him. Stick to the plan.
Rough ground slows you down. Should have listened.
Your route works. Sometimes the plan is right.
Your scout disagrees on the direction. 'That way leads into rough ground. I know a better path.'
Route Dispute
Trust his judgment.
His route is clear. He knows this ground better than you.
Leave him. He knows the way back.
He'll make it back. Probably. The patrol moves faster without him.
Send someone back to help him.
{COMRADE_NAME} drops back. You keep the patrol moving.
One of your men is struggling. He's limping, falling behind the group. The patrol can't wait forever.
Man Falling Behind
Wait for him. We don't leave anyone behind.
He catches up, grateful. The men notice how you treat your own.
Scout for a safer crossing.
No better crossing. You wasted time looking.
You find a shallow ford upstream. Everyone crosses safely.
Push through. Take the bridge.
The bridge holds. Barely. Everyone's soaked and shaken.
Send a scout to test it first.
{SOLDIER_NAME} tests the bridge. It's stronger than it looks. You cross carefully.
A river crossing ahead. The current looks strong, the bridge half-rotted.
Dangerous Crossing
Ignore it. Keep marching.
Your boot flaps with every step. By evening, your foot is raw.
Quick field repair while walking.
Sloppy fix, but it holds. For now.
You tie it off without breaking stride. Good enough.
Report to {SERGEANT} for proper repair.
He sends you to the supply wagon. You catch up later.
Your boot strap snaps. The column keeps moving. No time to stop.
Equipment Problem
Ask {COMRADE_NAME} for help.
He takes some of your gear. Together you keep pace.
Fall back to the rear guard.
You drop back with the stragglers. {SERGEANT} marks it down.
Push harder. Close the gap.
You push but barely keep pace. {SERGEANT} notices your struggle.
You dig deep and catch up. Your lungs burn but you're back in formation.
Your legs burn. The column pulls ahead. You're falling behind.
Falling Behind
Quickly grab what you can.
{SERGEANT} sees you break formation. 'Eyes forward, soldier!'
You snag a handful and catch up. Extra rations tonight.
Keep marching. Not worth the risk.
You stay in formation. The berries pass by.
Report the location to {SERGEANT}.
He sends foragers back. The company eats better tonight.
You spot a berry bush just off the path. Ripe fruit. The column keeps moving.
Foraging Opportunity
Take some of his gear.
You shoulder his pack. He nods gratefully. You march together.
Keep your own pace.
You push ahead. He falls back to the stragglers.
Report him to {SERGEANT}.
{SERGEANT} sends him to the wagons. The men give you cold looks.
{COMRADE_NAME} stumbles beside you. He's pale, breathing hard. Won't make it at this pace.
Struggling Comrade
Navigate carefully yourself.
Your foot finds a hole. You stumble, twist your ankle.
You pick your way through. Others follow your path.
Rush through to keep pace.
You stumble twice, catch yourself once. Your knee is bleeding.
The path ahead is treacherousâ€”loose rocks, hidden holes. The column presses on.
Terrain Hazard
Warn the men behind you.
You call back the hazards. The men behind navigate safely.
Bluff your way through.
He spots it immediately. 'Did you think I wouldn't notice?'
You adjust your stance. The officer passes without noticing.
Quickly borrow from the man beside you.
He slips you a spare. You owe him.
Stand tall and face the consequences.
The officer stops. 'Disgraceful, soldier. Extra duty for you.'
You're in formation. Something's wrong with your kitâ€”a missing buckle, a torn strap. The officer is three men away.
Kit Problem
Accept humbly.
'Thank you, sir.' You keep your eyes forward. The men respect that.
Puff up with pride.
You can't hide your satisfaction. The men beside you roll their eyes.
The officer stops in front of you. 'This is how a soldier should look. The rest of you, take note.'
Singled Out for Praise
Look away nervously.
His eyes narrow. He makes a note. You've drawn attention to yourself.
The officer stops in front of you. He stares. Says nothing. Just... stares. Something's wrong.
Stand firm. Meet his gaze.
He grunts and moves on. Whatever he was looking for, he didn't find it.
Suspicious Attention
Help, but let him know it's extra duty.
You help, but make sure he owes you one.
Help him willingly.
You spend the afternoon at the forge. Hard work, but you learn a few tricks.
Refuse. You have your own work.
He shrugs and goes back to work alone. The other smiths notice.
The camp smith is overwhelmed. He catches your eye. 'Could use an extra pair of hands.'
Smith Needs Help
Cannibalize another piece of gear.
You sacrifice one piece to save another. The math works out.
Improvise something that works.
Your fix is temporary at best. It'll need proper repair later.
You forge a replacement from scrap. Not pretty, but it holds.
Report the shortage to {SERGEANT}.
{SERGEANT} notes it for the quartermaster. The proper way.
A critical part is brokenâ€”a buckle, a clasp, something small but essential. None in stock.
Missing Parts
You step back and look at what you've done. This is some of your best work. Clean, solid, professional.
Show it to {OFFICER_NAME}.
He inspects it carefully. 'Fine work. I'll remember this.'
Stay humble. Let the work speak for itself.
You say nothing. Someone notices anyway. Good work finds recognition.
Quality Work
Cut corners. Get it done.
Done fast. Done badly. It won't hold.
Explain that proper work takes time.
He's not happy, but he sees reason. You do it right.
{OFFICER_NAME} appears. 'I need this fixed NOW. We march at dawn.'
Rush Job
Work fast. Quality might suffer.
The repair fails within hours. Should have taken more time.
Your hands fly. It's done. Not your best work, but serviceable.
Confront the most likely suspect.
He swings first. You're both bloodied before others pull you apart.
He crumbles under your stare. Confesses everything.
Investigate quietly. Don't tip off the saboteur.
Word gets out that you're sniffing around. The trail goes cold.
You start asking careful questions. Someone knows something.
Report to {OFFICER_NAME} immediately.
The officer takes charge. An investigation begins.
This damage wasn't from use. Someone cut these straps deliberately. Sabotage.
Fight through!
You charge the ambushers. Steel rings. You cut through, badly wounded.
Flee! Ride for your life!
An arrow finds your shoulder. You barely stay in the saddle.
You spur your horse. Arrows whistle past. You escape, bleeding.
Arrows hiss from the treeline. You've ridden into an ambush.
You throw down your weapon. They take you prisoner.
Estimate from this distance.
You count what you can see. Rough numbers, but useful.
Get closer. Count their numbers.
A sentry spots you. You run, arrows biting at your heels.
You crawl close enough to count banners. {LORD_NAME} will want this.
Report immediately.
You ride hard back to camp. The news alone is valuable.
Smoke rises ahead. You crest a hill and see itâ€”an enemy camp. Hundreds of tents.
Enemy Camp
Go to ground. Let them pass.
You press into the brush. They ride past, oblivious.
Enemy patrol ahead. Six riders, moving slow. They haven't seen you.
Shadow them. Learn their route.
They sense something. You break off before they spot you.
You follow for an hour. Their patrol pattern is now yours to report.
Enemy Patrol
Withdraw quietly.
You slip away. Better to report what you know.
Capture him.
He fights back. You take him, but not without cost.
You run him down. The dispatches are valuable. So is the ransom.
Leave him. Not worth the risk.
You let him ride on. Your mission is reconnaissance, not combat.
Observe and let him pass.
You note his direction and markings. Information without risk.
A lone enemy rider, unaware of you. He's carrying a dispatch bag.
Lone Rider
Note it and continue your route.
You add it to your report. One discovery among many.
Mark it for later report.
You note the landmarks carefully. This could change the campaign.
Return to report immediately.
You ride back with the news. {LORD_NAME} is pleased.
A game trail leads through the hills. It could cut a day off the army's march.
Hidden Path
Backtrack to the last known point.
You retrace your steps. Time lost, but you find your bearings.
Climb high for a better view.
From the ridge, everything makes sense. You reorient and continue.
Push on. Trust your instincts.
Hours wasted. You're more lost than before.
Your gut was right. You find the route and press on.
The landmarks don't match your map. You're not where you thought you were.
Follow the tracks.
They spotted you. Arrows fly. You barely escape.
You trail them to their camp. Valuable intelligence for {LORD_NAME}.
Note the direction and continue.
You mark the trail on your map. Good information without the risk.
Return to report immediately.
You ride back with the news. {SERGEANT} appreciates the caution.
Fresh tracks in the mud. Many riders, moving fast. They passed within the hour.
Fresh Tracks
Push through the storm.
Rain lashes your face. You're soaked and cold, but you complete the route.
Dark clouds roll in fast. The wind picks up. A storm is coming.
Find shelter and wait it out.
You find an overhang. The storm rages, but you stay dry.
Storm Coming
Turn back before it hits.
You retreat to camp. The mission incomplete, but you're alive.
Challenge them properly.
It's {COMRADE_NAME} returning from patrol. Good protocol.
A figure approaches your position in the darkness. Friend or foe?
Shoot first, ask questions later.
You nearly kill {COMRADE_NAME}. Everyone is furious.
You drop an enemy scout. {SERGEANT} commends your vigilance.
Approaching Figure
Wait to see who it is.
It's one of ours. You should have challenged them.
Hope no one notices.
{SERGEANT} finds you asleep. You're in serious trouble.
Report yourself to {SERGEANT}.
{SERGEANT} replaces you. He respects your honesty.
Your eyelids are heavy. You catch yourself nodding off at your post. This is dangerous.
Shake it off and stay alert.
You force yourself awake. The rest of the watch is torture.
Fighting Sleep
Challenge them yourself.
They attack you. You fight them off but take a wound.
You confront them. They flee. You prevented a breach.
Raise the alarm immediately.
The camp responds. The infiltrator escapes but the breach is sealed.
You spot someone climbing the wall near your position. An infiltrator!
Shoot them down.
Your arrow finds its mark. The infiltrator falls.
Challenge the movement.
An arrow whistles past your head. You dive for cover and raise the alarm.
Your challenge reveals nothing. You stay alert.
Raise the alarm immediately.
The camp responds. It was just a deer, but better safe than sorry.
You spot movement in the darkness beyond your position. Could be an animal. Could be an enemy scout.
Movement in the Dark
Watch carefully before deciding.
You identify it as an animal. No need to wake the camp.
Complain to {SERGEANT} about it.
{SERGEANT} is annoyed by your complaint. 'Just do your duty, soldier.'
Leave your post. You've done your time.
You abandon your post. {SERGEANT} finds it unmanned. Serious consequences follow.
Your relief is late. You're cold, tired, and your shift ended thirty minutes ago.
Stay at your post until they arrive.
{COMRADE_NAME} finally arrives, apologizing. You held your post.
Late Relief
Extra drills until his attitude improves.
He drills until his arms shake. The defiance fades to exhaustion.
Make an example of him. The others need to see consequences.
Latrine duty for a week. He seethes, but the others snap to attention.
Take him aside. Find out what's wrong.
He listens, but you don't reach him. At least he's not causing trouble.
He's scared. Hiding it behind bravado. You talk him through it. He falls in line.
One recruit refuses to follow instructions. Arms crossed, jaw set. The others are watching to see what you do.
Difficult Recruit
Give him extra challenges. Push his limits.
You pair him with veterans. He rises to every challenge. One to watch.
Note it quietly. Tell {SERGEANT} later.
You mention it to {SERGEANT} after. 'I'll keep an eye on that one.'
Praise him in front of everyone.
'This is what I want to see!' The recruit stands taller. The others take note.
One recruit stands out. Quick learner, good instincts. He's better than the others by a wide margin.
Natural Talent
Send him off. Continue training more carefully.
You send him to the surgeon and slow down the drills. Balance.
Push through. Training stops for nothing.
'Walk it off!' He limps to the side. The drills continue. Harsh lesson.
A recruit goes down hard. He's clutching his arm, face white with pain. The others freeze.
Stop training. Treat him properly.
Your field medicine is rough, but he's stable. Someone fetch the surgeon.
You set the bone and bind it tight. He'll mend. The others see you care.
Training Injury
Ask for his guidance.
He steps in and demonstrates a technique. You learn something new.
{OFFICER_NAME} appears at the edge of the training ground. Arms crossed, watching your methods.
Show off. Demonstrate your best techniques.
The recruits fumble your advanced drill. Embarrassing.
You run them through complex formations. Impressive work. He's smiling.
Stick to the basics. By the book.
Standard drills, properly executed. He nods and walks away. Good enough.
Officer Watching
Answer honestly. He deserves the truth.
You tell him the truth. It's not pretty. He nods, thoughtful. Better he knows.
Change the subject. Not the time for this.
'Ask me after your first battle.' He accepts the deflection. For now.
Give him the harsh truth. No sugarcoating.
'It's messy. It's loud. And it stays with you.' He goes pale, but he needed to hear it.
During a break, a recruit approaches. 'What's it like? Killing a man, I mean.'
Hard Question
Isolate the sick. Quarantine.
You set up a separate tent. The fever doesn't spread further.
Report to {OFFICER_NAME} immediately.
The captain orders quarantine protocols. The right call.
Two men came in with fevers. Now three more have it. This could spread through the whole camp.
Contagion Risk
Treat them together. Work faster.
You work through them quickly. Risky, but you get ahead of it.
Give him everything you've got.
You did everything right. He slips away anyway.
Hours of work. Your hands are steady. By morning, his fever breaks.
Stay with him. He shouldn't die alone.
You hold his hand. He talks about home. Then silence.
This one's bad. Deep wound, lost a lot of blood. You're not sure he'll make it through the night.
Difficult Case
Focus on those you can save.
You make him comfortable and move on. He dies quietly.
Accept his thanks.
'Just doing my job.' But his gratitude is real. Word spreads.
Brush it off. Move to the next patient.
You nod and move on. There's always more work.
{SOLDIER_NAME} grabs your arm as you finish changing his bandage. 'You saved my life. I won't forget.'
Grateful Patient
Clean it out. This is going to hurt.
It wasn't enough. But you bought him time.
He screams but holds. The flesh is clean. He'll keep the arm.
Fetch someone with more experience.
The company surgeon takes over. Knowing your limits is wisdom.
The wound is red and hot. Smells wrong. If this spreads, you'll lose the arm. Or the man.
Watch and wait. It might clear on its own.
By morning, the swelling's down. Sometimes the body heals itself.
Treat the officer first.
He dies on your table. The soldiers glare. A waste.
You save him. The common soldiers mutter, but officers look after you.
Quick stabilize the officer, then treat the others.
You stop his bleeding quickly, then move to the soldiers. Everyone lives.
An officer needs treatment. He's bleeding badly, but so are three common soldiers waiting their turn.
Officer Down
Treat them in order. The officer can wait.
'Fair is fair,' you say. The soldiers nod. The officer is not pleased.
Improvise. Tear up spare clothing.
Your makeshift bandages hold. Barely.
You make do with what you have. The wounded don't complain.
Ration what's left. Prioritize the worst cases.
You stretch the supplies thin. Some wounds go untreated today.
Send word to the quartermaster.
Fresh supplies arrive within the hour. Crisis averted.
Bandages are running out. Two more wounded and you've got nothing left to bind their wounds.
Running Low
Execute a captured deserter as example
Address the company. Promise better days.
Petition the lord directly for emergency resupply
Spend personal funds on emergency supplies
Your sergeant-major reports in low tones: "We've lost six already. Slipped away in the night. More will follow unless something changes. The men are watching you, Captain."
Desertions Imminent
Report them to the sergeant
Stay silent about what you heard
Talk them out of it quietly
A week of hunger. In the dark before dawn, you overhear voices: "Three more days of this and I'm gone." "There's a village two leagues south..." They haven't seen you listening.
Whispers of Desertion
Arrest him for desertion
Let him go. Pretend you saw nothing.
Give him your wages to send home
Private Aldric—one of your best—is packing his kit in the dark. He freezes when he sees you. "I'm sorry, Sergeant. I have a family. I can't die here for nothing."
One of Yours Is Leaving
Implement rationing across the retinue
Send foraging parties immediately
Request resupply from the lord

Supply Officer's Report
Eat quietly and conserve energy
Share a portion with a weaker soldier
Try to get extra from the cook
The cook's portions have shrunk. You notice men eyeing each other's bowls, calculating. Nobody says it aloud, but everyone knows: supplies are running low.
Thin Rations
"It's temporary. We've been through worse."
Share your own ration with the squad
Assign extra foraging duty to the squad
Your squad clusters around the cook fire, muttering. The portions are visibly smaller than last week. They look to you—their NCO—for answers you don't have.
Your Squad Grumbles
Public punishment for the worst offenders
Open your personal stores to the men
Demand the lord provide resupply
Multiple fights have broken out across your retinue. Your sergeants report men hoarding scraps, stealing from each other. The rot is spreading fast.
Discipline Breaking Down
Step in and break it up
Watch and stay out of it
Get the sergeant

Fight at the Cook Fire
Punish both harshly
Mediate and split the ration fairly
Share your own ration to end the fight
